Posts.Content: May 13, 2015 10:45AM - edited May 13, 2015 10:23PM by Rosevalley Dianna50 - said it well.."there is much to be sad about." She is right, so it's not like your perceptions are off and your are making much out of nothing. There is lots of uncertainty and fear and unknowns about life in cancerland. Especially with young children and all the roles we need to play. IT'S HARD!!! Pat yourself on the back that you recognize you are having difficulties and are asking for or thinking about interventions. If you need antidepressants try them and it doesn't mean you will need them forever either. If one doesn't work, there are others. There are lots of threads where the women talk about different antidepressants and the SE and how long they took to work. It might be good reading to check those sites and see if any of the meds appeal to you. Then ask your PCP or MO and get more information on what suggestions they might have. We take so many meds that getting clearance from your PCP/MO about what you are taking and what options will work with your treatment is a good idea. Have you used a therapist or know of one who might be able to help you? I wish you luck getting relief. Vent and explore your feelings here - we all get it. BCO is safe territory. I have been very depressed before (arimidex made me depressed) and it so sucks! (((Hugs))))

Posts.Content: Dec 18, 2015 04:24AM Rosevalley wrote: I feel for you and have walked miles in your shoes. It's awful. The nausea and pressure is relentless. I have had ascites symptoms since May. They did serial paracentesis until sept when I got a Pleurx catheter. I love it. I am draining everyday now 600- 1000 off. I instantly feel better. Sometimes I get cramping and it aches and or I just get tired and have to lay down. The main thing I want to impress upon you is that your quality of life will improve immeasurably once that catheter gets placed and it heals. It hurts a bit to put in, take your meds and in a couple of weeks you won't notice it. Then the fluid comes off easily! Relief is at hand. They send the bottles to your home. I hope my story gives you some hope. I pray you get the catheter and can enjoy the holidays with your little boy. By the way the Tuesday before my pleurx placement they took off over 3 liters. That following Friday they placed the catheter and took off 2.6 liters just 3 days later. I could breathe and did much better after that. I noticed you also have Lobular breast cancer. It's hard. I also have 3 kids older than yours. My youngest is 14 and has a hard time with my having cancer. Prayers for you and love sent your way.

Posts.Content: Apr 1, 2015 10:20AM Rosevalley wrote: I agree the first episode with the children was hard to watch. My DH bailed after and hour.. muttering too depressing. Still we both marveled at the history of the March of Dimes, and the Jimmy's Fund. I was struck with the second episode at how political things were and how behavior was manipulated by products. The example in 1900 lung cancer was rare, no one smoked. Then WWI troups were given cigarettes, got hooked, brought the habit home, thus was born a lucrative industry. Lung cancer deaths soared.. it took decades before the statistics matched what was told consumers! Here we always think "SCIENCE" drives medicine. I think they made a very good case that aint always so! Even that one high powered surgeon smoked and died of lung cancer. It wasn't until the government stepped in to force the issue, put warnings on cigarettes, tobacco was too big and powerful. I wonder how diet and soda now plays into this now, and electronic toys, exposure to phones and such. I was also astonished at the insulated opinion camps and how those believing in one paradigm refused to even entertain any truth from other camps.. virus, chemicals and genes... the blind men describing the elephant. Wonderful analogy. Now that the science is proven and the data in we can see how wrong and harmful these treatments were. Open minds work. I love the quote- by the fellow who drove the mastectomy off in favor for the lumpectomy- show me the data. The public and God can have trust and hope, but science needs data. If some were not brave enough to question, to be the Galileos and stand truth to power, where would we be? Still thinking the earth was flat and treating with leeches! This is a very powerful film. I have learned a lot. I am sure that woman with the triple negative who got the first dose of herceptin and is cancer free just feels like the luckiest guinea pig on the planet. Can't wait for episode 3.

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2013 08:07AM - edited Jan 16, 2013 10:27AM by Rosevalley It's nice that they did this introduction. The information sharing is wonderful and I wished I had logged on back in 2007 when I was diagnosed with stage IIIA Inv. Lobular Cancer. The treatments etc. is below. I was diagnosed in April 2012 with wide spread bone mets, multi. rib breaks, "avid" spine, humerus, femurs, ribs, clavicle, sternum and pelvis. I was sore but really had a hard time believing the extend of the bone mets. I had a couple of stunning bouts with back pain, but it got better so "how could it be cancer?" Denial is a wonderful thing I guess. But once treatment started killing the cancer and my counts dropped off, 2 units to bolster what was left of my bone marrow's ability to make blood and the reality sunk in, yep stage 4. Since starting faslodex and zometa my TM have dropped from 768 to 68. Pet scans went from loaded to clear in Sept. so I dare to breathe and plan again. This stage 4 thing does a number on long term planning and picturing yourself in the future. My Grandmother died a particularly miserable death of IBC when I was in college. The images and fear I had around that have been hard to shake. I know things are different now. Tamoxifen had just come out for my Grandmother and it was why she lived well for 2 years before the cancer overwhelmed (bone, lung, brain mets) her in the 3rd year of her treatments. I did get BRCA testing since there is  quite a bunch of prostate cancer, breast and ovarian cancer in our family. thankfully it was negative. I have been married for nearly 25 years, to a great easy going guy. He's been very supportive. We have 2 adopted kids ages 19 and 11 and a wonderful surprise gift (age 17) in the middle. Our 2 imported models are deaf (the first one we didn't know and the last one we requested a deaf child). My kids are just terrific and all so very different. I figured with all the breast cancer stuff we had enough on our plates, but apparently not, because in 2011 our oldest child's liver started to fail and she is being watched for eventual transplant. Never a dull moment here! Otherwise we are all healthy! We  all love animals, so we have 3 cats, 3 dogs, one rabbit and a canary. My husband grumbles that we needed a barn -  not a house! Oh well a furry lap warmer for everyone!

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2013 07:23AM Rosevalley wrote: That's wonderful about the "Gotcha Day" Adoption day celebration. We know lots of famlies who celebrate their kids arrival. But she also made me laugh! When I shaved my head she signed - "Daddy's gonna be mad at you!" We just live every day and hope for the best. So far so good.

Posts.Content: Sep 11, 2014 10:00AM Rosevalley wrote: I can't speak for Bill Gates decision to give 50 million for Ebola except that maybe it's a political thing. Gates has done remarkable things for HIV around the world. What would happen if everyone on the boards asked the Gates foundation for money for MBC? No harm in asking right? If 1000 letters showed up.. What if the sign said I got my mammograms on schedule and still got late stage breast cancer! Or as a post suggested above 1 in 3 women with breast cancer will have it spread and get Metastatic breast cancer. We could have like 2 signs, educating people. I live near a huge high school nearly 2000 kids. Also up the street is an elementary school with 500 kids. All those parents and care givers and kids seeing the signs gets people discussing the issue. Hey Mom "what does metastatic mean? Wow Auntie did you know 1 in every 8 women will get breast cancer in their life time? Is there breast cancer in our family? " Then a discussion on standards of care, mammograms, who in the family has ever had BC etc. Maybe a good graphic logo to cue folks to the topic.  If we leave thing as they are then we will be treated as a regretable chronic condition and placed on the back burner... oh well nothing to be done except tread water until it's over. I hope this thread stays open with the idea that any of us with an idea can come post it. Then that might lead to another member seeing it and thinking..."what if we took that further..?" Then one idea leads to another.  Perhaps by putting our collective minds together, unified and focused, we can come up with a funding campaign for MBC research. We all need a cure.
Posts.Title: Puketober and elections making the US population aware Rosevalley Rosevalley

Posts.Content: Rosevalley wrote: As I was driving in to town today, I couldn't help but notice all the political signs up. They peppered the landscape. We have all complained that the whole PINK Komen thing doesn't address MBC suffering and that there isn't enough done for us. I agree with that. What would happen if there was a campaign with large signs that stated - Living with Metastatic Breast Cancer. A sort of Awareness campaign like they did with autism. The numbers are stunning. What if all over the country these signs were posted in October to illustrate the extent of the problem. Or bumper magnets. I know it's giving up a degree of health privacy but silence betrays the sheer numbers affected. Do any of you think that might fly? Imagine driving through the neighborhood.. oh there's another sign... and another..... and another.. It hits home the extent of the problem. Frankly, I think signs should go up showing the astronomical numbers of all women affected by breast cancer. Imagine what seeing a sign in every 8th front lawn would do to people's complacency. You can't get involved, donate and care if you don't understand there is a health crisis. Double mastectomy 07/ chemo ACT, Radiation/ 07 Arimidex, 08 Aromasin, 2012 Faslodex, 2014 Afinitor / mets spine, bones 6/2015 mets to omentum, malignant ascites, lung, liver/ 2016 Herceptin, Doxil, Faslodex. Ibrance, Taxol, Abraxane, Navelbine Dx 1/2/2007, ILC, 6cm+, Stage IIIA, Grade 1, 1/17 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Dx 4/2/2012, ILC, 6cm+, Stage IV, Grade 1, 1/17 nodes, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Dx 6/1/2015, ILC, 6cm+, Stage IV, Grade 2, 1/17 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2+ (FISH) Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2014 06:53PM - edited Sep 29, 2014 07:05PM by Rosevalley Yep AC is like being hit by a big transit bus. I took  Emend and when that stuff wore off, I found the inside of my mouth just sweating saliva. I mean I drooled uncontrollably, I was so nauseated! I leaned my head down and saliva just fell out of my mouth.. gross. I had compazine but it was oral.. I thought what a joke trying to swallow that. I did manage to get it down. My onc at the time was like why didn't you take the compazine?  Well I generally wait until I have a symptoms before I take a med like that.. who knew how long the Emend would last? Emend is great stuff. Chase it with compazine or ativan when it wears off, otherwise it's just unbearable.  AC is damn awful. I won't share the rest of my journey. I did manage to get through 3 cycles of AC but it was truly one of the worst experiences of my life.  It so sucks. The Cytoxan burned my bladder and now I have no feeling in it. I have had 2 UTI's in the last year and could feel no pain. The only way I knew I had the UTI's was my urine stunk so badly I asked for a UA to check it out. I drank tons of water after the infusions just like they said, but it didn't help. Taxol was no better.. the neuropathy has plagued me everyday of my life since I finished 4 doses. Had I to do it over again.. I wouldn't touch taxol with a 10 foot pole. So kudos to you for getting through that!  Get Emend; try it.   You know I am curious - you are stage 4 right? Why are they slamming you with AC? I took ACT when I was stage 3A. It was my understanding that once you are stage 4 the name of the game was smaller palliative doses that check the cancer and keep it from spreading. You can't cure it. Ask your onc to reduce the dose. If you are getting the big bang doses they give to stage 1-3 BC patients then I wonder why? AC has risks.

Posts.Content: May 13, 2014 09:27PM - edited May 13, 2014 09:35PM by Rosevalley Great post above with good suggestions. Definitely take the antidepressants again. Not good to dump those cold turkey... nasty side effects.  I do not generally crave sweets. I love crunchy salty things. I will say you can train yourself off certain tastes. I have edema and some heart issues so i need to be on a no added salt diet. My daughter has liver failure and she had to be on a no salt diet. So we started being the typical salt junkies like most of America. It's been 3 years and now regular lunch meat makes me gag! It tastes just like nothing but salt. Most processed foods are inedible! I love no salt chips and salsa. I don't even enjoy or like the tastes of regular salty food. SO it can be done. Once in a while I will get french fries... then I'm good. I try to get the value fries because the portion is small. I know that many sugar free foods are pretty darn tasty! Baskin Robbins has wonderful sugar free ice cream. Sugar free candies are pretty good. A piece of dark chocolate is a real treat.  The trick is, limiting it to once a week. Don't try to go off all sweets cold turkey. Gentle changes are easier to keep. If you tumble off the wagon, be kind and loving to yourself. Then hop back on. Really good ripe fresh fruit can be just as good as sugary sweet things and way better for you. Put lite cool whip on it.. yummy. I just thought of something we do that might help. We all like melon. So I buy it and cut the whole thing up in chunks and keep it in a big bowl. Sometimes I add strawberries or grapes. So there is always this bowl full of ready to munch on fresh fruit. The kids like it in the morning with vanilla yogurt on it. I can eat it either way. It keeps you full and your potassium up with out breaking the calorie bank.

Posts.Content: Jun 23, 2014 04:35PM Rosevalley wrote: Raro - wonderful post. I think what you mentioned is true. If you are ever able to walk through most ICU's it will amaze you how many folks are frail and elderly. Do their families not expect them to die? Why are the end days of life spent in such a place? It's miserable and there is little spiritual quiet healing or preparation for death. We should all want the best possible death for ourselves, one considered and thought out, met head on! It's our right! If you were healthy and got in a car crash and needed support and life saving measures - GREAT! They can do that for you. Or a life threatening infection, surgical complications, organ failure, on an on.. then yes ICU will throw all they have into seeing you through. Yay for medicine and advances!! But when you are 85 and have multiple medical issues.. why put yourself through that? A code is pretty drastic and many folks are never the same after they have been through one. My own Dad was a train wreck at 74 when he died. He looked 100! Thankfully he put his requests into writing. Age is very relative when it comes to health. I have seen 55 year old train wrecks and 95 year olds who looked like they were 60! Best we put our wants and desires clearly into our advanced directives!

Posts.Content: Dec 28, 2013 01:27PM Rosevalley wrote: Welcome Addie, I could really understand your comments about CP being a part of who you are that you don't pay attention much. I think that perspective is missed by others. It also sounds like you really get around! That's super makes life interesting. Even rock climbing wow! I am afraid of heights so rock climbing is out. Thank you for sharing part of your life. Your attitude is awesome. My Aunt raised a zillion Golden Retrievers for Canine Companions for Independence. CCI trains these dogs mostly Goldens and Labs for wheel chair assist dogs. They can open doors, pick up keys and dropped items, and help in so many many ways. It is just incredible what they teach these dogs to do, plus they are "companions" too! I am a  dog lover, so I agree with you if you think you need a dog then you do! Finding the right fit so that you both benefit, is the part that takes a while. I would ask CCI if you would qualify for one of their service dogs. They really are just fury angels. I have a disabled daughter (autism, MR, deaf and CP right) We got a Golden retriever for our daughter and he was her constant shadow and keeper. (Our service dog was a CCI reject, failed their testing for wheel chairs but was a fantastic companion animal)  My daughter and Banner were joined at the hip! I knew he would keep her safe and focused and she dearly loved him. We had him for 10 years and he died of cancer at age 12. Even though she would sign to him and she doesn't talk, their bond was remarkable. Truly they communicated in ways others just do not understand. He was our furball angel. I hope you find a dog that bonds with you in the same way.

Posts.Content: Nov 24, 2013 12:53PM Rosevalley wrote: It's interesting my last MO had me on it every month then spoke of taking me off it. We had the discussion that many oncologists out there disagree and would continue zometa, but the drug has a crazy long half life and stays in your system for ages. IV Zometa is a very potent long acting biophosphate. It's over kill he thought and more is not necessarily "better" medicine. As Caryn pointed out all these drugs can have risks and everything you take has to be cleared out of your system by liver or kidneys (few other ways but mostly those 2). So just take what you really need. It's interesting to share the dosing schedules with others here, because it shows how things are changing. I have noticed that I had an increase in peripheral edema with zometa and faslodex together. Since being off, the edema has tapered back nicely at the end of summer, still get some, but not as bad. I have absolutely NO idea if this is related to anything and might be utter coincidence. (Obviously not scientific.. etc. and there could obviously be other reasons.)

Posts.Content: Jan 7, 2013 03:31PM Rosevalley wrote: Wow flash backs to 2006 for me. For years I was told I had fibrocystic breasts with dense tissue, the left breast felt NOTHING like the right. I asked repeatedly about why it felt so different, thicker, like a dense nurf ball. I was brushed off and told i was a worry wart and to relax.  I do have family history of breast cancer and ovarian cancer. I had had 8 mammograms by the time I was diagnosed with stage 3 breast cancer at age 48. I had had a "clear" mammogram just 8 months earlier. What I had was lobular breast cancer, which doesn't show up worth a damn on films. If you line up my films side by side you can see it growing and pushing out the tissue. Every year or two, I  got my "clear" report.  By the time they took the thing out it was over 6 cm. You could see it with the naked eye on my breast. It measured 4x5cm and all that showed up on mammogram and ultrasound was 1.5cm. They did a core biopsy and found cancer and still believed the damn films instead of what they could see and feel and measure! I had a 1.5 cm lymph node full of cancer that didn't even show up on any film! They found that during the sentinel node/ lumpectomy. So don't let them blow you off. Demand more investigation. I believed my professional OB-GYN, Radiologists, Surgeons, oncologist etc... and they were all wrong. I have 3 kids and was diagnosed in April with wide spread bone mets. Not to scare you but lobular breast cancer is 15% of all breast cancers and the least likely to be picked up with films and most likeley to be underestimated in size. It is still just as deadly.    I'll be praying that you have a big old cyst but make sure you check it out thoroughly -especially if it stays.

Posts.Content: Rosevalley wrote: Just finished reading the article by Peggy Orenstein, "Our Feel Good War On Breast Cancer." We get the New York Times on Line paper. It's an interesting read. 108 women die of breast cancer ever day and yet 0.5% of all National Cancer Institute grants since 1972 focus on metastatic disease. Komen wants you to believe they spend $$$ on research but 3.6% of a total budget of 2.2 billion raised (6 yr period) went to research. Crazy numbers eh? We (stage 4) are the failures of the "cure." Exceptions for sure, but not many. Once your nodes are positive, the horses are outa the barn so to speak! My 1.5 cm node was bigger then many folks primary tumors. I think it is strangely misleading to tell women they are curable with node positive disease. Truly in all this pink stage 4 is absent. Maybe we should get our own color.. Posts.Content: Aug 10, 2014 10:36PM - edited Aug 11, 2014 07:17AM by Rosevalley The only cure that I know of for that creepy feeling of being hunted down by the grim reaper, is staying firmly in the present moment. It takes fortitude (more than denial ) and discipline of living moment to moment and refusing the pull towards darker thoughts and leaving loved ones behind.  We can not escape sickness and we can not escape death. By living mentally in the present moment we transcend fear and loss.  It is hard to get to know these lovely women by their posts and wit and humor, only to see them suddenly vanish. Spam girl and Chickadee hit me hard. It's a virtual world here but too surreal when the women vanish.  So ENJOY that 50th Birthday! You have lived it. You have earned it. Savor it with your lovely sons and DH. Be the Birthday!

Posts.Content: May 1, 2013 06:22PM Rosevalley wrote: Scuttlers. You are so right. It would be much less frustrating and irritating to write it down and hash it out. I did not bring a list of expectations or needs to this new oncologist. I have tried being  forward and asking for what I need but have not gotten anywhere at all. I am told I don't need that, and it will go away what ever it is. It is so frustrating, like the movie Ground Hog Day.. he wakes up to relive the same day and same dialog - over and over.  I just pick up and leave since it's a Sisyphean task to stay and continually bring up issues and have them ignored or swept under the rug. The pain thing mystifies me.. it's not like you can fake a PET scan or xrays.. no I fudged those mets and rib fractures! If most mets patients live for 26 months why are the doctors so stingy??? I do have great pain tolerance; lots of practice.. I just keep on going, but aching gets old. If you wait until I am in serious pain to scan, then you might as well send me to hospice. I have had 3 scans in my cancer journey-one at the start, one 6 yrs later and one 4 months after that to see if tx was working. The 2nd one was loaded. It took 6 years for an oncologist to check a tumor marker and when I finally got one it was 768.  I still did gardening and carried on..sore. It was like I had to prove having a problem and I can't prove what I ate for lunch. Our insurance does limit what is available as far as choice in doctors. I live in Oregon. I don't know if what you have in your relationship can be found here. I am so disgusted I don't know how much effort I want to put into it. My husband tells me.. if not for you - then do it for the girls. if I was single... I would have thrown in the towel by now. I bring very specific written questions to my daughters GI and liver transplant appointments. If I can't be there, then I give the question list to my husband who takes her. Pediatric physicians are much less gamey and as direct as they can be. If they don't know, they say so. I love that. I actually get an answer to my questions, even if it is "we don't know.". You can't say they are not as over worked as the adult side.. their offices are jam packed and appointment list a mile high. Our experiences in Peds offices are totally different then adult medicine.

The pop and soda wars were comical. Hoagie and subs.  I never picked up a Philly accent because my folks were from the midwest. It took just a few vowels of anyone from the Midwest to say "barn" or something with a long "o' and I knew instantly they were from the Midwest. I can pick out Baston accents, Rhode Island, New York and Maine. My Grandmother was from a small town in Indiana bordering on Kentucky. She had some funny sayings, going to go "trade" (buy something.. trade $ for goods), crick (creek), rutz (roots). My husband can mimic a Longha island accent, wadder the dawg, go for a wak in da Park.. hilarious. He has family on Long Island. I was working once as a cashier in a super market (Jersey shore) one summer as a teen, when this little old world woman asked me for Doona. I said what?  She yelled "doona where it at?" Doona? Then exasperated she shouted Doona Feeesh! Tuna fish... ugh complete with spit.. Oy...

Posts.Content: Rosevalley wrote: Since I have noticed others use the kindness of the boards for rants and release... forgive me I am going to do the same. It's cheaper then counseling. One year ago I finally got a GI doctor to do a PET scan and diagnose wide spread bone mets, small compression fx T something and multiple rib fractures- everything but my head, hands and feet lit up. I went to an oncologist (my6th - oncologists 3,4,5 refused to do any labs or testing of any kind)and this doctor did a bone biopsy (yep same ILC same grade etc..) and started me on faslodex. He gave me a script for norco written 5/300 no refills... it's supposed to be 5/325. So of course the pharmacy wouldn't fill it and had to call... this is day one of our relationship. Seeing the no refills I asked my PCP to fill the Norco she did but required a narcotics contract be signed and placed in my chart. That pissed me off - who does this to a stage 4 bone mets patient with rib fractures? Anyway, it took a long time but the ribs healed and things got better. Except for sleep, can't sleep for beans. I toss wake up etc. So I was using the Norco for sleep, gradually weaning off. My PCP knew this. I have chronic back pain and have for years. I took Celebrex for a little over a year and it worked great- LOVED it... until it started giving me stomach pain and mouth ulcers. NSAIDs all of them do that to me. Great drugs.. mouth ulcers suck. So make a long story short. No more NORCO. Fine. I go to renew the Celebrex... no more Celebrex either. I asked the MO and PCP for sleep meds.. sorry no sleep pills of any kind- try meditation or relaxation tapes. Ya right. I have one place on my back that gives me constant aching pain. The Mo said your tumor markers have gone down to 48. Your last scan in August was clear, the cancer is there but nothing active. So no new scans. We will stop the zometa and maybe make it once a year. hmm. It's just your chronic back pain. I can't argue that. I am frustrated and tired. Everytime I see the NP she tells me "how refreshed I look!" She changes the subject when I bring up the sleep issue. So I changed MOs. The one good thing that Mo did was increase my diuretics to get the increased edema off my feet and legs. I had neuropathy from the taxol that I thought I beat..but the edema was irritating the nerves and it came back. The diurectics worked great. Couldn't stand the new MO. Called back and said I'll pass. She said she wouldn't scan unless there was something new. Agreed with the other oncologists I saw who did no labs or testing - no scans zip. You have to wait until symptoms warrant it. I said you wouldn't even do a tumor marker check? No she said they aren't accurate on everyone. I said if you never check them ever -how do you know if they are meaningful for that patient? No answer. They happen to be accurate or correlate with my scans. How can you tell if you always have pain issues? "I still won't scan."  I have a redundant colon and always have digestive issues.. so nothing is new. Everything is a matter of degree. None of it feels good. The faslodex increased my leg edema, made me tired, made it harder to sleep, sometimes transient nausea, but was better then the AI's which I refused to take.  Needless to say I thought why sign up for more of the same with this oncologist. I called back and said no thanks this isn't a good fit. I wished I had them flush the port.. it hasn't been flushed since March. I can't stand the irritation of going into another doctor and feel I need a break from this carnival ride. I hate the idea of ever going into a oncologists office again. Then there is my DD deaf daughter who was diagnosed with end stage cirrhosis at age 17. We have been worked up by a CA transplant team and need to wait until she gets sick enough. Slowly over the months they have increased her diuretics. She is 19 and on 100mg of spironloactone and 40 of lasix and they can't increase because of her kidneys. She is tiny 4 foot 8 inches. She should weigh 80 to 83 pounds. Over the last month her weight has increased from 87 to 90 pounds,; we used to freak when her weight hit 85. She has had pleural effusions from ascites. None right now. She has stretch marks across her abdomen, butt and all the way to her knees. Her belly is bloated and full. Her labs are all normal. Hows that for compensating.. except for low creatinine clearance and INR (which they fix with vitamin K). we are waiting to see an nephrologist.. there is talk of lupus, maybe or kidney issues on top of her needing a new liver. You can't get a MELD score until your labs go higher. So we wait. Last night she said she was full. She wouldn't finish her dinner. This morning she woke up, said she was full - we tried on so many pants.... none fit. (No more 14, 16, into junior 2, 3... thank goodness for sweats and leggings. Her little arms and legs are so skinny.). I ask continually -"can't you do something about the edema?" I am told to wait. So we wait. This is so frustrating. I am so sick of doctors and chronic disease... ugh. This all sucks. Double mastectomy 07/ chemo ACT, Radiation/ 07 Arimidex, 08 Aromasin, 2012 Faslodex, 2014 Afinitor / mets spine, bones 6/2015 mets to omentum, malignant ascites, lung, liver/ 2016 Herceptin, Doxil, Faslodex. Ibrance, Taxol, Abraxane, Navelbine Dx 1/2/2007, ILC, 6cm+, Stage IIIA, Grade 1, 1/17 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Dx 4/2/2012, ILC, 6cm+, Stage IV, Grade 1, 1/17 nodes, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Dx 6/1/2015, ILC, 6cm+, Stage IV, Grade 2, 1/17 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2+ (FISH) Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2014 05:12PM Rosevalley wrote: Kjones- if you look at most of our meds on the list of side effects is...INSOMNIA. Not only do we have to put up with the other side effects, there is sleep deprivation. I am convinced when you get a good nights sleep everything is more tolerable. I think you have less depression, less pain, better tolerated side effects when you have had enough sleep. Why NPs and Oncologists are stingy or overly sparing with sleeping pills & stage 4 cancer patients is a mystery to me. Ativan doesn't do anything for me. Restoril made me move constantly all night like a whirling dervish. My husband called it "restlessville" instead of restoril. Melatonin 6mg doesn't last, although it sometimes helps get me to sleep. Melatonin has a very short half life and is safe and won't make you groggy in the morning. Sometimes I will listen to meditation tapes or soft music if I am too wide awake. Mostly, I find that by the end of the day I ache enough, back and feet bothering me, that pain meds are what get me to relax enough to fall asleep. Otherwise I just toss and turn and can't get comfortable. Thankfully I can have meds for that. I feel your pain, as this has been an ongoing issue effecting my quality of life for 7 years! We have lots of company. I wish there would be a sleep med just for cancer patients.   Good luck.

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2013 09:18AM Rosevalley wrote: I was dignosed in April 2012 and flat out asked my oncologist about prognosis. He said 1-2 years generally. I started faslodex and zometa and have watched my tumor markers dive from 768 to 68. My broken ribs have healed, comp fx to my back healed and in general I feel much better. My PET scan went from loaded to clear in Sept. I asked again so what do you think? He said "you'll be around for a while." After looking at all the other women and reading their stories, I think I might have a chance at NED and many years of quality life. I am happy about this. I just wish I didn't have the old images of my Grandmothers BC journey and ending, firmly playing in the back of my brain. She lasted 3 years, the last year was pretty awful. I think once I get past that 3rd year I'll be able to relax. I try not to think about it. I do wish someone on this stage 4 forum would talk about what works for getting and staying asleep. Sleep and not having it be broken up into 2 hour blocks drives me nuts. Everything looks better when I get enough sleep. Why would binding estrogen make sleep so disturbed?

Posts.Content: Sep 3, 2014 11:51PM Rosevalley wrote: There is another interesting Book called The Cure Within, by Anne Harrington. It's a history of mind-body medicine from placebo effects, to astonishing cures, the effects of meditation on the body, secrets and pain in the subconscious that make a person physically ill etc.. very interesting read. I think in the end science will find more mind-body connections then they think are present now. If anyone snaps that your attitude made you sick, (absurd) shoot back-" Oh I guess the babies and toddlers who die of cancer had poor attitudes and killed themselves? Really?" That should hit home that no one picks cancer with their attitude nor will a deliriously pollyanna out-look save your life.

Posts.Content: Aug 24, 2014 07:06PM - edited Aug 25, 2014 03:18AM by Rosevalley You know they did a study once on toddler's eating habits. If anyone has ever had a toddler you know how notoriously difficult they are to feed! Picky, obstinate and they like something one day and refuse it the next. It's enough to drive a parent crazy. Well in the study they allowed toddlers access to a buffet of options and just let the little ones eat what ever they wanted out of the food options. They recorded the end total in nutrition, calories etc. You know what they found? If tiny 2 year olds were left to choose, they actually met theeir nutritional requirements over the course of a week, not each day - the sum total of what they ate was enough. So that meant the kids knew intuiatively what they needed to eat. Internal cues were telling them - carrots today, little more protein tomorrow.. citrus! Here in America we have access to a fantastic variety of food year round even, so it is easy to "eat well." I think Americans worry too much about food. If we just use variety and stop eating when we are full, we will more than meet our requirements. I agree with Caryn, eat what you enjoy and ditch the worry. There are some things to be careful with. I had all my kids vitamin D levels checked and mine, right before I was diagnosed with BC in 2007. We live in Oregon where it is cold and rainy 8 months or more a year. So folks are not always out getting their "sun." I came back low. My one daughter was critically low (turns out her liver was no longer making/ processing the  vitamins A,D or K) and she had chronic liver disease, any change in diet wouldn't have helped. My other healthy kids were also low  or barely normal. We eat a great diet, varied etc. But you need sun light. So now everyone in the house gets 2000 units. So depends on where you live and exposure. Most supplements only give you expensive pee!  I can see where Dr. Valero makes a nice case that "You have lived with cancer for a very long time and functioned well. Things can continue on the same path indefinitely." Maybe what he says is true in the institution where he works. Maybe they look for recurrences and treat accordingly and follow-up on SE and symptoms. I hope for your sake that it true. I certainly have not had that experience at all.

Posts.Content: Jun 29, 2014 02:16PM Rosevalley wrote: I am so sorry you are having a hard time with the side effects. Having to cycle through many treatments and have them not work must be frustrating and scary all at the same time. Maybe an antidepressant might take the edge off? None of them work right away but your PCP or Onc might have a suggestion for you. Perhaps it would help? You are in tough times and "going into dark places" is not unusual. I am sure your husband and sons don't want you to feel like you are putting them out!  I almost went to hospice in Jan. I didn't want to try anything else -sick of all of it. Sick of being sick, anemic, pain - feeling like shit. My daughters - all 3 of them wanted me to try anything - something else. Pleeeease they begged. I was useless.. I spent days getting blood transfusions, was too tired to do squat. The kids wanted me there anyway, even all gimpy and useless. It took a while to find something that worked, and that has side effects too. All the treatments do. The name of the game is to treat the side effects not just suffer in silence.  When I was bald my kids were embarrassed of me too. I remember taking my hot wig off in the car driving down the freeway. Here I looked like Uncle Fester from the Adams Family - fat, shiny bald and puffy from prednisone! What a sight! My daughters slunk down in their seats horrified.. "Mom people are staring!" I said let them! I'm too hot with that wig on! We tried to make it a joke after that. Since I couldn't fix it might as well laugh at it. They lightened up after that. I teased them and gave them dark sunglasses.. then they felt silly. I wish you fortitude and patience with your sons and how you feel. You are not alone and you are not unusual in how you feel. I am sure most women with kids and stage 4 cancer/ treatments could affirm they understand completely!! This is crazy hard.  Lots of ((((HUGS))))

Posts.Content: May 12, 2013 11:05PM Rosevalley wrote: Pain is such an interesting topic since our brains decode what we feel and attach meaning to it. Each person will describe something a little bit differently. prior experiences play into our perceptions too.  For me the joint pain of arimidex was like ground glass in your joints, just unrelenting aching and pain. I just didn't want to move. Even my accupuncturist tried leaving the needles in and could not get rid of the hip pain. I used to just LOVE my sessions, because Tagasshi could get rid of all the pain after chemo... I slept at times during accupuncture. But 6 months of the joint pain.. whew did me in. I wasn't given any pain relievers. I finally quit the drug and that got rid of the pain. Neulasta shots were horrid. Like an intense pain from the inside out, everywhere and nowhere specific. Intense... it was doable because you knew it ended after a couple of days.. take the percocet. ugh.. nasty. In the weeks leading up to my PET scan in April of 2012 I kept feeling this odd tingling sensation in my sternum and different places. I never felt anything like it and didn't know what to make of it. I couldn't decide if it was painful or just wierd. It was bone mets, but I didn't know it at the time. I also had a rib that clicked when I would breathe, but it didn't hurt. Then my other ribs started to ache on the right. That was small fractures, couldn't lay on my right side after a while. All of this annoying, but didn't stop me from activities. Those feelings were all bone mets; they hurt but didn't nail you. Interestly, once the treatment started the faslodex and zometa made the pain worse not better. It took months of treatment to really feel better. I have one area in my back that when I stand for long periods or sit it just aches like heck and won't stop. Yet the scans say clear.. the pain stays on. Oh well. To this day when I think of a pain score of 10, I remember splitting the bone in my lower leg as a ten year old. I fell off the edge of a barn roof.I screamed and rocked back and forth on the ground, in just crazy intense pain... off the charts. That is still my "10." To this day nothing hits that level. Four huge gall stones and a "knife in your back" and I would rate that a 9. I have had a couple of crazy painful back injuries and still 9s..8s. Bone pain like a quick long fracture is the worst. I was just frantic I hurt so bad and could hardly pull it together.. crying and gasping. I spent the entire summer on my back... leg up. ugh. I have heard that bone cancer and bone pain is excruciating. This I can believe.How is it in some cultures a woman is supposed to be silent during birth and in other cultures scream through it all? Is it expectations and patterning, "it will be like this" and you behave accordingly? Like little kids who skin their knee and if they are engaged keep playing, but if Mom is watching... on come the tears!

Posts.Content: Mar 21, 2013 02:40AM Rosevalley wrote: This has been an on going issue for me for since I got thrown into chemo induced menopause 6 years ago. The Ai's all but erased my ability to sleep and faslodex has made my sleep all chopped up into 2-3 hour bits. I was taking Norco at night for rib and bone pain, and it worked for that and helped me sleep. The ribs are healed which is good. The Norco doesn't help me sleep now-good for back pain and headaches. I am chronically tired. I tried a ND recommendation of valarian and HTP that seemed to work maybe 1/2 the time. But my husband pointed out I stayed up all night one night and crashed the next, so maybe he was right. I need to take a fist full of melatonin and it only works for an hour or 2. I asked for prescription sleep meds from my PCP she said no. It was a battle to get 0.5 mg ativan (no refills) and it didn't do much if anything on a recent trip. As a matter of fact I am wide awake 11:30 and I took 1 mg ativan 1 1/2 hrs ago - zip -  I am up writing this and reading posts. My kid's need to be up at 5:45 to catch a 6:20 bus and I can't wait for the alarm to go off so I don't have to toss and turn, up and down. Lack of sleep is the single biggest irritation about the whole cancer experience, and nothing seems to work. Then the next day I feel so tired I just kind of fog through the day and doze in the chair. Thank goodness for dermablend make-up to put under the bags under your eyes. Great stuff! If anyone cracks the sleeplessness of breast cancer treatment- POST IT! Then tell me how you got your PCP/ MO to order it.

Posts.Content: Sep 25, 2012 02:40PM Rosevalley wrote: When I was first diagnosed back in 2007 our 3rd daughter was 6 years old. We had adopted this little peanut. I felt horrible that she might lose her Mother TWICE. How could I do this to a little kid. My guilt just knew no end. Until I started to come around to understand life is precious because it is fragile and brief. No one wants cancer. I vowed to love my girls best i could for as long as I could and give up some of the anxiety, fear and saddness.  This didn't happen over night, so be gentle and kind with yourself. You deserve compassion and time to get through this initial shock. My Grandmother died of inflammatory breast cancer so I had watched that as a college kid decades ago. Breast cancer just scared me to death. I had to reevaluate my old fears, because treatment options have changed so drastically. You can live for years and years managing breast cancer like a chronic disease. So if you have fearful cancer memories examine them and know that many things have changed for the better! Laughter helps alot. When I shaved my head at the beauty parlor, my 6 year old blurted out, "Daddy's gonna be mad at you!" I laughed. We teased our border collie with the wig I had. She barked and flew around like it was "alive!" My kids roared. It was hilarious. I mortified my 11 year old by driving down the freeway bald and beautiful. She slunk down in the seat horrified. We teased each other and laughed. You will too. Humor helps so much. Also, use the ativan, the anti emetics (emend rocks) and take your pain meds. Be comfy and there for your child by taking care of yourself too. It's a big club and we are all in the same boat. Hugs and fortitude!

The cancer will win I know that. I am selfish I want 10 weeks. I might not get them. Need to pick out a cremation place. No services or obit... blow the sand away. Posts.Content: Aug 27, 2016 01:30PM Rosevalley wrote: Thank you for your posts about DH's sister. She was a happy person, loved to swim, eat, enjoy favorite TV shows and was just a sweet heart. My DH wanted to say good by but a fast death beats a slow one. Now she is free of disability and flying free. She lived a charmed life and was lucky in that she had stellar support and well educated parents who loved her. No hidden away family here. She had rights and respect and love. Ruth my DH ooohh and ahh over Stella! He was like "cutest puppy ever." We used crate training for house training and swear by that. You do have to train yourself that tiny baby bladders need frequent trips out and all positive rewards. Praise and tummy rubs and positive reinforcement. If our puppy went to chew something she shouldn't we had a can with pennies that made a sharp startling sound that we shook and then said "no!" That worked. Then give them puppy nyla bones, kong toys with peanut butter are a great treat. No raw hide. It's all about learning what is ok to chew and what is off limits. We don't allow dogs on the beds. We have a huge Costco round bed and our border collie sleeps in her bed. Not on people beds. So you have to decide on what rules you want to enforce. Make sure you give her a good quality food. Enjoy her she is sooo cute. Nice to have a dog and cats. What do the 2 old brothers think of Stella?

Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2016 05:08AM Rosevalley wrote: What a lovely picture and beautiful old cherry tree! Thank you for thinking of me. I just had to post good news. I saw the oncologist today and my tumor markers have dropped from 929 to 708. Yay that's a 221 drop in a month! The doc said she never sees faslodex work so fast and she is learning new territory from my body's response and how dire my situation was (and how many chemos I have pooped out on.. doxil, herceptin, xeloda, ACT from 2007, aromasin& afinitor, arimidex and femera.) We talked about adding Ibrance but not yet. I told her my drain amounts have been slowly decreasing. My albumin and total protein is better, not quite normal and my liver enzymes are perfect! Kidneys and blood counts are all normal. I have cancer in my mesentery, liver and lung, omentum and bones. So I got my faslodex shots and xgeva shots and will forge ahead. I still need the reglan and have to eat a low residue diet for food to go through and my stomach to empty, but I will take it! Thank you for all your prayers for well being, because they are working. May we all be happy and free from suffering. Hugs. love to all rosevalley

I did try buspar years ago and it made me feel very weird and out of it and I didn't like driving with the med on board. Needless to say I didn't last long and quit taking it. Posts.Content: Apr 24, 2016 01:43AM Rosevalley wrote: Loveroflife- Yes when I read her post my heart just ached because I KNOW what it's like. I have walked many miles in those shoes. I have also had coworkers whose marriages have failed because of the stress of a special needs child. Some special needs kids are very sweet and the journey is hard but not evil hard. Then there are those few kids who are non verbal, very destructive, busy and aggressive when their impulses are restricted. It can literally be a safety issue for parent and child. No one deserves to be hurt, bit and hit. There are special homes where staff are trained to deal with persons whose behaviors are challenging. There is no shame in admitting a child is out of your league and you can not parent them effectively or safely. It's ok to admit that and move them into an evironment where they can get what they need. I hope that Mom can find such a place. I was walking my dog yesterday and it started to rain. We were hurrying to get back home. I started to walk past a neighbors fence just next to her driveway and she pulled into her driveway so fast she nearly mowed us down. When she opened the garage door to pull in, her dog barked and my dog spooked and pulled my arm. I lost my footing and fell in their driveway a real belly flop on the cement. It really hurt. My knee is banged up and with wide spread bone mets and being 57... I am so SORE!! I hurt everywhere. My neighbor who did this just stood in her garage and didn't even go out and try and help me out. I live 2 houses across the street from these folks Some man in a car stopped to ask if I was ok and I managed to get up and walk home. Nothing broken just sore. Note to self no falling on the cement at my age!! Rules to live by. Thank you for all the wonderful pictures. I love them. I wish I had a Iphone so I could take pictures of my garden. It's so pretty.. rhodies and lenten roses. Irises and so many blooms.. violets in bunches. I will have to wait to weed until my knees heal. Chevy your garden is so sweet. I love the picture of the doves Jazzy. I love their sound.. cooing. Be well sisters. I thank you for your friendship.

Posts.Content: May 14, 2016 06:24PM - edited May 14, 2016 06:29PM by Rosevalley Thank you for your kindness and encouragement. I had a little cry over my disappointment at faslodex fizzling out and decided I have xeloda and Ibrance yet to try. My oncologist wants me to start Ibrance Wednesday to line up with my next appointment and labs. So down the hatch on Wednesday. Pray it gets me through the summer. The thought of leaving my 15 year old alone in an empty house while DH is at work just upsets me. I feel like I failed everyone. I know in my heart this is not my choice or fault, but when you are a Mom you agree to be there for the long haul...18+ years. The unspoken Mom pledge- I will watch your back, feed you, take you to appointments, support and love you.... every day until you fly off on your own. Unless cancer mucks up the works. I am sad about Nancy dying. Glad she is free from cancerland and suffering, and sorry to see a wonderful soul leave. I know we all die and I accept that, but she was young and loved. It's hard. Some how when you are in your 80s it seems ok to die and natural, but before that it seems sad. Realistically I have packed a lot of life, learning, love and experiences in my 57 years and feel my life was/is really sweet and fulfilling. I didn't miss anything. Not that I wouldn't love to see marriages of my daughters, graduation from college/ highschool and Grandkids someday and to grow old with my DH, but I feel I packed quite a bit into my 57 years. It's been a good life. No regrets when I die. Life is good. I am grateful. Thankful for everybody and everything. Lovingkindess to all. Speckle neckle the chicken is very pretty! I like to watch chickens they have a lot of personality. My oldest DD loves to feed the chickens at a nearby community. They eat right out of her hand and she just laughs and squeals with delight. They are also beautiful.. blacks, speckled, brown and white chickens. Some are quite big.

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2013 12:47AM Rosevalley wrote: Years ago back in 2007 during the dose dense misery of ACT I had diarrhea from IV one. Everyone else seemed to be trading recipes for blasting caps to relieve constipation. Not me I nearly pooped myself inside out and bought diaper cream to relieve the skin irritation at 48 years old...ugh. My oncologist finally told me about glutamine powder, actually he gave me little packets to mix. I believe it was 3 grams to a serving. I then went and purchased it at a health food store. This stuff works wonderfully! OMG what a difference that made. I wanted to belt him for not telling me sooner! Relief!!! It's been years and 3 grams sticks in my head but I would check the amount with your oncologist. The stuff works.

Posts.Content: Jun 19, 2014 05:36AM Rosevalley wrote: I parked behind a woman who took up 1 and half spots near the front of Lowes. This was back when my anemia was crazy bad and everything- walking just wiped me out. There was a woman next to me, who remarked "I can't believe the selfish way she parked!" She must have written a note and left it on the car. When I got out, that note was on my car flipped over where she wrote all kinds of nasty things, calling me pretty immature names that I parked behind her and she needed that space for her stroller and I was an asshole etc.."  I couldn't believe the extent of the harangue! I didn't write the note. She also assumed I meant to make life harder for her when in fact she was gobbling up 2 spots right near the front of the store! I have a retarded, autistic deaf kid and another kid 2 years younger and I never needed 2 parking spots to get my stroller in! Let me tell you there is nothing faster than an autistic kid on a mission! People can be so selfish and mean.

Posts.Content: Jun 11, 2014 04:01AM Rosevalley wrote: I can't get over the comments made by co-workers, family and friends. I for one am sick to death of the comments "you look good!" Does that make the cancer go away? The last oncologist I had, had a NP who was just insanely upbeat, cheerful and happy all the time. She would say to me "You look so refreshed!" I complained over and over about insomnia and achiness.. and was met with silence, no support  and "you look refreshed!"  I finally said, "yes dermablend at 35$ tube can cover the darkest of under eye bags." So we try and muddle through, cover up our cancer and minimize the SE. The world doesn't want to know about the cancer - what happens in cancerland is supposed to stay in cancerland. It's an unfair burden on top of everything else. When family asks how folks are I rattle off about my kids, pets and DH and leave it at that. It's easier.

Posts.Content: Aug 6, 2014 02:16PM Rosevalley wrote: You know until you get a chronic disease that requires a lot of intervention, you don't understand how expensive it is to pay all these medical bills. How does that pay for your kid's braces and car repairs etc..??? You have to go over 7% of your income before the feds will even allow a deduction. It's crazy. We had excellent insurance too BC/BS.. thank goodness or the whole ship would have sunk! I feel your pain smiley... it's a terrible shock to the mind and the wallet. Thank goodness for OBAMA Care or we would really be toast!

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2014 01:57AM Rosevalley wrote: Raro- lots of good advice. acupuncture works. I have a Philips Blue Light I sit next to. I bought it at Best Buy and you just sit next to it for 1/2 hour a day. Takes the edge off. We live in the Pacific Northwest and it's crazy rainy and overcast, from November to May. I get SAD every year - sucks. I lived 5 years in Rochester and the constant snow got to me. UpState New York is lovely, but this has been the winter from hell. Think of the Lilacs to come! Cancerland sucks. No doubt. I came within weeks of throwing in the towel and calling it quits right after Christmas. My kids guilted me out of heading to hospice and trying more treatment. It's hard to look in their faces and give up. But I too am sick and tired of being sick and tired. Seven years of this and no end in sight. For weeks before Xmas I needed transfusions, sometimes every week.. too tired to do anything when your 5.5. But things have improved  enough that it's been 10 plus days and I go in tomorrow for 2 more units. Anemia sucks. Plugging along.. hoping to see my kid graduate in June. Carpediem - Planting sunflowers indoors in Dixie cups and watching them grow has been a winter past time for my kids. It's planting hope that some day SOON, the clouds will part and the sun will shine. The sunflowers will grow. Then you can watch the antics of the birds and squirrels trying to eat the seeds!

Posts.Content: Sep 16, 2014 10:32AM Rosevalley wrote: You will eventually use up your veins and the scar tissue will make it more and more difficult to access the peripheral sites in your arms. You will have to get a port eventually. Sooner would be better then later. I have a small power port that has been in since 2012, no issues. Ports can stay in for years and years. I don't feel mine and you can't see it. Beats being stuck to pieces. The only advice I can offer is to drink lots the day before your infusion and wrap your arm in Warm blanket before they attempt an IV. Good luck.

Posts.Content: Feb 26, 2013 11:23AM Rosevalley wrote: Breanda true- it must be endemic the weird and wacky way folks respond to stage 4 cancer. The first email i got from my sister in law asked me if the bone mets hurt and how long did they think I had. Really? Pretty amazing. She's married to a doctor. I really like this person and she is usually pretty nice funny. That took me off guard. She emails frequently but doesn't mention cancer too much. She will ask about the kids. I appreciate that. I keep her posted about our kids, which are nearly the same age There just isn't too much you can do with folks who are uncomfortable with stage 4, dying or being reminded that folks do die of cancer and that it can take years. I think they run out of things to say... oh you are still here.hmm Now what do I say - kind of thing. I am always reminded of how insensitive folks can be. I have had a number of neighbors ask how long do I have. Like I know? I hope years.. I would never ask anyone that question. I guess you just grease the social wheels in your family and try not making a big deal of their goof ups.. moving on. Maybe to show them how to behave. I also think it's good to just ask folks for what you need. Sometimes we just have to take care of ourselves and not worry about what the others are doing.

Posts.Content: Jun 1, 2016 11:00PM Rosevalley wrote: Kandy... wow you are brave!!! Two shots on one side. That's an 18 gauge needle and long! Owiee... I can't imagine having a hip replacement on one side and faslodex shots on the opposite side. You are a strong woman. Wow. My nurse today is one of my favorites and she is gentle and so sweet. The shots didn't even hurt. The Xgeva shot stings.. oh well that can't be helped. I just wish the faslodex wouldn't wear off so fast. The Ibrance doesn't seem to be working. My gut has stopped. Food is backing up again. I was nauseated and puking Saturday, yesterday and this morning. I hate puking. I have taken zofran twice today. I just feel lousy. My poor husband is all sad. I am sad too we need this to work for the summer so I can be here for my daughter age 15. It just seems things are worse. I am pulling a lot more fluid off my belly, peeing less and the N/V. The labs I had drawn were perfect and better then they have been. Tumor markers that were drawn today won't be back until Friday or Monday. Still all indicators are the cancer is more active, N/V more ascites fluid and bloating. The Ibrance appears to effect my neuropathy in my feet and I forgot to tell the Oncologist about that. The puking and nausea scares me and I don't want to get back to the state I was in Dec-Feb. Ugh that would be awful. Now that I got more faslodex may it work fast. Thank you for your prayers and support it helps me cope and i am so grateful to you all. (((Hugs))) Love to all rosevalley

Posts.Content: Jun 6, 2016 12:26PM Rosevalley wrote: Madelyn- Yes my daughter and husband made it to Deaf Church. It's interesting my kids were raised Quaker for most of their young lives and then I began to attend a Sangha and learn about the teachings of Buddha. We once went to a retreat at a Buddhist Monastery and got an interpreter to make the event accessible for them. It was wonderful. But then my cancer came back in 2012 and slammed me. I have not had much energy to engage in Sangha. I practice at home but not outside. Sitting meditation and walking mediation needs to be done as I am able pain tolerance and all. Most of my reading is Buddhist in content. But I am very familiar with Christian teaching having taken Old and New Testament in college and done much reading. My youngest has decided she wants to join Deaf church and be Baptized. I respect her decision to follow Jesus if that gives her life more meaning and purpose. We all have to find our way. My DH's first boss was a Catholic who fell in love with a Muslim Indonesian and converted. They were so happy together. I went to a Franciscan College and became friends with the some of the Sister's and have so much respect for them. Through the years meeting folks and listening to their stories I have met many from different faiths who have been happy and fulfilled. They have been my world religion teachers. I now know that there are many paths up the mountain. I know that my path may not be my daughter's path and I support and respect her right to choose her own way. They seem very nice at the Deaf Church. We have gone with her to services. I still feel lousy. bloated and queasy. The Ibrance needs to get swallowed yet. ugh dreading it. I am tired of cancer. I want to be open and brutally honest about the effects of cancer. Why because our society has turned it into a pretty pink ribbon. There is nothing pretty about the reality of breast cancer; it's awful, disfiguring, life altering and kills way too many of its victims. I like the roses. Will you make a blanket? My MIL made us 3 crocheted blankets and we fight over them they are so warm and toasty. Today was almost 100 and no blankets. Whew I will be glad when the weather breaks. Too hot. Forgive me for rambling..

Posts.Content: Jun 23, 2016 03:38PM Rosevalley wrote: Clemens Gardens is lovely what a wonderful tribute to a beloved spouse! There is healing and magic in a garden and people know that. Try being sad and miserable in a beautiful garden.. nearly impossible. Like trying not to smile when a baby giggles, children laugh or small animals are being playful. It lightens the heart. When my DD1 was in the hospital we walked around the garden at the Children's hospital and we did it daily ski jacket on over hospital jammies and admired the plants, sculpture and small birds that lived there. It helped us heal as muchas the testing and medicine. Good for the soul. Ok you stage 4 folks will appreciate this. I went shopping for a few things for my youngest kid. Jeans on sale and got a great deal. I never buy things for myself thinking I am going to die within the year and what's the point? So I have lost weight and many of my clothes look like sacks.. one set of pjs fell off. I had to get rid of those. Kohls had a tremendous sale and I bought 4 shirts! I just can't believe I did it. They were crazy mark downs under 8 bucks each! (They had been 36$) So if I drop over on Friday's infusion I told my friend they are hers. She said I was crazy. But I keep thinking should someone with cancer everywhere and malignant ascites buy new clothes in the light of such a limited life span? I have to admit they look nice and feel good. Well as nice as a boobless, left arm bigger then the right (lymph edema), middle aged woman with thinning hair can look. Good thing I love being alive more then I care what I look like. Zoloft helps too! Thanks for listening to me and for all your kindness, support and sharing. Coming here makes me smile. JLF I am going to ask about Taxotere if it might be better tolerated. Thanks for the heads up.

Posts.Content: Jun 25, 2016 03:41PM Rosevalley wrote: I didn't know that all these drugs were variations on a theme... using different delivery systems to get into our bodies. Taxol, Taxotere, Abraxane etc. Cancer drugs never stop surprising me how they are tweaked to find their ways into our cells. Learning something new every day. I am happy there is a taxol I can take since it clearly works against my cancer. .. for now anyway. I am a little frustrated with my body's acceptance of these drugs. I seem to always have some issue. I had forgotten that the 3rd dose of dose dense Taxol 2007 made blisters break out on the soles of my feet. They dropped the dose by 33% for the 4th dose and I had no feeling in my feet at all. It took months to return and the feeling is not the same. The fluid they gave me today had given me pretty severe edema.. had to get out the lasix to get the fluid off. Way too puffy. I met a neighbor today undergoing breast cancer treatments, brain, bone, liver... we connected instantly through our gardens and mutual admiration of plants. We live just around the block from each other. She is taking a combo that I tried and I told her the taxol story. We both love the same types of shady plants hostas and rhodies and our husbands were commiserating. Small world. We are probably near in age even. There are just tooo many of us with stage 4 cancer. It's awful. I liked her and hope she does well and we meet again to talk. We have lots in common, sadly. I took 2 walks the steroids make me antsy. My neighbor said all the brain radiation makes her tired. Cancer is hard. They heal in their garden just like we do at our house. Make me well or at least feel better dear plants - heal me. Calm my mind, clear my thoughts and capture my imagination dear garden, keep me grounded and still to grow. Plant therapy. Good night all. (((hugs)))

Posts.Content: Jun 29, 2016 03:28PM Rosevalley wrote: Ebru- my DD2 loves to make things in the kitchen but she isn't so good at the cleaning up part. The boring part. It's my fault since I gave her donut pans and all matter of baking items. I love to cook, and like trying out vegan recipes for her. I just wish she was vegetarian since there are so many things to make, vegan is harder. She is an art student and there is by nature a creative energy and mess that goes along with good art. She's a good kid, hard working great grades and works part time at a coffee shop. Then there are friends and places to visit. Cleaning in't her thing...pots and pans especially. :-) So I clean periodically... oh well. Makes me happy spoiling her. Mominator- You really did get close to that bunny. When I was in our Pennsylvania high school a friend and I would wake up hours early and ride our bikes through Ridley Creek State Park and up to high school. Kathy and I enjoyed our startled pheasants, quail and bunnies we would see riding in the early morning. It was magical -deer in the fields and so many animals. It was worth the cool morning ride and painful steep hill at the end to bike through the park before school. I rarely see bunnies here in Oregon maybe because there are so many raptors- Eagles, Hawks, Kestrals, Owls are just every where. I know back East bunnies were much more prevalent. Up at the cabin I saw Owls and Eagles and Osprey but rarely bunnies. In the 8 years we had the cabin I only saw maybe 8 rabbits.. and lost count the number of owls and osprey and eagles. I miss seeing the salamanders and slugs and mushrooms I would find on my walks. I miss the old growth woods. Yes I ate my comfort grilled cheese and tomato in my new shirt. It felt wonderful to have something fit. To be able to eat something and have it nourish and feel good and not make you sick. That's a blessing. Simple things really are the best. Like cool lemonade when you are thirsty. A homebaked cookie warm from the oven. Nothing fancy just good and simple. Company with friends. Prayers and meditation time to center. It's all good. Making a life while having cancer takes intention and thought. Lovingkindness to yourself and others too. good night. rosevalley

Posts.Content: Aug 25, 2016 03:06PM Rosevalley wrote: You know that book the Tribe is a small book but very very interesting on community mental health, belonging and disconnect in society. It was a very interesting read. I read a book review in NYTimes and thought can't stand it - must read it. I am glad I did. Everyone who cares about QOL not stuff, should read it since there is so much about history that we can learn from. I love that the settlers who left the colonies to live with the Indians routinely never sought out to come home. If they were forceably returned they left to go back to the tribe. Who would have thought? I will be interested to know what you think Stephanie. The Lion King was stunning. We were kind of high but center. SO the full effect of the stage and sets and costumes was just wonderful The music and sound quality was great. The puppet animals and the way they moved was just magical. My DDs all loved the birds and dancing. I had to sign the story in parts and make explanations during the laughter and music. Some parts are hard to make "deaf" meaning. The story is universal with an African theme. The young king returning to find himself and reclaim his rightful place. A myth for us all finding out who we really are. Great music and I loved the stars/ night sky. We enjoyed it. I had to take a couple of pain pills to sit that long and got myself in a position I couldn't get out of..causing pain. But we had a great night out. It was lovely. I still have a couple of weeks to get through before school starts after labor day. I went for chemo today and talked to the oncologist. She said she was surprised the markers jumped so much and I was so symptomatic so fast on one week off. My albumin and total protein dropped again causing the increased ascites. My liver enzymes are just a bit elevated and my white count must be ok because they gave me gemzar. So we will see what happens in the next 2 weeks. I feel like I should drain but I would like to wait just in case the chemo circulating is in that fluid. Let it sit for 8 hours and pull it off tomorrow. Of course tomorrow the steroids will sustain me and then I will crash and feel awful Friday. My DH is so the eternal optimist... he told the oncologist I ate an entire piece of terimisu (sp?) cake and didn't puke. (It was fiercely yummy and I decided that if I did puke- it was blooming worth it.) We went to a special desert restaurant with DD3 for a treat. It was practically the only thing I ate that day. He also said my last drain went down! All happy.. it was 12 hours not 24 hours. That's why the number was decreased. I drained early to have a good time at the show and not be bloated. He tries to see any little improvement as "getting better" sustaining. It's cute and kind of sad. Really things are not better at all; they are slowly and distinctly getting worse. I keep telling him that and he just can't accept it. But there is the next couple of weeks to endure. As fast as things are progressing, unless magic happens, he will need to accept my leaving. My oncologist wanted to add carboplatin to the gemzar but that would mean more N/V. I made a face. We are sticking to gemzar. Tumor mrkers should be back tomorrow. Wish me luck . Thank you for your pictures and kind words everyone. I love the puppy Ruth! Stella's super cute. Lucky you to play Grandma!

Posts.Content: Aug 29, 2016 10:28AM Rosevalley wrote: Sorry you didn't like the book Stephanie- Funny I didn't get the impression it was a thumbs up on the military machine as much as the mechanics of making a tribe. Under what circumstances do folks make a tribe- disasters coming together (earth quakes), war and conflict, economic collapse etc. What circumstances cause people to act collectively and not individually. Having adopted an older kid with clear PTSD from being abandoned multiple times before the age of 4, I appreciated the PTSD comments and how PTSD symptoms are hard wired to protect us. I thought the book was good as far as he went with it. I would like to learn more about Colonial men and women leaving society to stay with the Indians. We almost bought in to a co-housing situation here in Oregon in 2007. It is a big regret that I didn't go for it. I would have been much better off. I was so shocked by the advanced breast cancer diagnoses and it being the same side as my Grandmother that I figured why move- I would be dead. I ended up 10 years down the road. Who would have thought. I really wanted the community part of co-housing. We have no relatives here in Oregon, all family is East or in CA. The community was so popular that the wait list is years. I think we would have been better off as a family and certainly for DH as a single parent. What you give up in privacy and individuality you get back i n collective living, shared experiences, support and common purpose. We took the safest economic route which was to stay put in our ranch house in our neighbrhood. We have some friends here that are helpful but people by and large keep to themselves. Folks at DH's job have really helped us during times I have crashed. I think that is true of our society. There is this individual bent to modern society and not a collective mind set. I"t's not my business what so and so does. I would be intrusive and need to butt out." This isolates folks. I see it with older folks, single parents and families under going crisis - illness, job loss, mental illness etc... People are afraid to intervene, check up on folks- just pop in to connect. This contributes to high rates of disconnect and depression. Poorer more rural, less "advanced" societies are far more connected. They have to be to survive. Maybe next life time I will get to experience community. I lived the entire house in the burbs, garden and stuff... it's nice but you can't take it with you and it's very labor intensive. Funny but community costs more to buy in to collectively owned lands and gardens and buildings but you get more.

ACT was that traumatic and miserable. I just signed up for taxol palliative doses pending insurance coverage. It's every week for 3 then one off. I figure I need 2.5 months. I will trade barfing for increased neuropathy but if it gives me till school starts then great. Oral pills are not an option they don't stay down. I can not believe I said yes to chemo every week. There must be an ICD9 code for this. I look like shit bald. Uncle Fester from the Adams family - really scary sight. On the up side I will go out looking like Buddha! Noni- my DD3 was adopted and has a lot of trauma from her early years being in an orphanage. There is mental illness from it all or genetics we are not sure. She still hordes food and hides it and has since she was 4 when she got here. All the years of feeding and loving and she thinks she will starve still. It's pitiful. When I die it will be yet another loss and abandonment in an already hurting heart. When we buried the pet rabbit she sobbed and cried.. the dog and cat too. Never mind the cat was 16 and the dog 18 and OLD! Life is full of separation and hurt. I am trying to instill in her that 40,000 loving Mommies and Grandmas die every year from this crummy disease and it is no ones fault. All she sees and feels is that someone who loves her and cares about her dies and leaves yet again. SIGH... what to do?? I just can't leave this kid alone in a house 9 hours a day while Dad works. I need to try and stay alive until I roundup some care givers and school starts. You are right that those lucky souls who get hit by a bus and taken out in an instant are spared having to think about what is being left behind. This is hard for me. I feel horrible guilt. I promised to be here for her and I can't. She drives me crazy sometimes and yet I feel very sorry for her. She hurts and is scared. I worry about the future and my DH's ability to cope being a single Dad. I feel guilty about leaving him too. But I can do something for 10 weeks. It's not forever. If it doesn't work then at least I tried and that voice in my head that says "Moms never give up," will be silenced. If I was single I would not do this. I am tired. Now to get through the days until insurance approval.

Now if I don't get it on Wednesday it bumps me forward and makes me sick (puky)on Thanksgiving. It's BS I tell you. Nothing goes right. Always some lame excuse of we didn't get the orders in time.. it's like the patients themselves have to follow up nag and bitch to keep the schedule the doctor tells them they are supposed to have. If you were a passive sit on your hands and wait for the office to help you type of patient--- you would croak. You would miss weeks of treatments and I wonder if they would even notice or care? Navelbine is a bitch too I puke part of dinner up every single night. sucks. I am getting to the point where maybe dinner needs to be taken out of the schedule. It's not worth the nausea, fullness, burping and vomiting. It's usually just one session of 3 or 4 vomits and then I feel better. Weird. It's definitely the chemo because the day before I am supposed to go in and it's worn off - I feel much better. Ah the joys of cancerland. Thanks for letting me vent..

Cricket (the border collie) was the best dog I ever had and the 3 of them would all sleep together.

Posts.Content: Nov 27, 2016 07:38AM Rosevalley wrote: My dear sweet Percy Cat has gone to Rainbow Bridge and back to the universal love that we all come from. I cried buckets and can't hardly look at his fur and paw print the vet made without crying. 16 wonderful years being loved by him and unless you've been well loved by a cat - head bumps, wiggling tail, purring so hard you can hear it across a room, face rubs, funny vocalizations when ever you talk to them, them running up the yard to greet you, fighting for lap space, bringing you dead trophies and kneading you with curly paws and toes... when a cat does all of this, plus love all your kids, tolerate being dressed up, pushed in dolly strollers and loved each family member in turn then you will understand why I am heartbroken. He's a family member by heart bond an exceptionally friendly cat. My little comforter and therapist too. DH dug a deep hole under the bench in the garden. Percy was sitting out there yesterday in the brief moment of sun we had. He spent many hours laying in the flowers sunning himself. We wrapped him in a lovely cloth and laid him in the soft soil, the kids wrote cards and we buried him with love. I am so glad I made it to be with him and send my love with him. He was down to 6+ pounds and his kidneys were going. So Kjones I am glad I got to be with him and the kids as we let him go DWD via our kind vet Dr. Johnson. It was closure pushing the soil over on his earthly remains. His wonderful spirit is flying free. Funny how we accept DWD for our pets and not so much for people. I wonder why that is.
