Posts.Content: Sep 16, 2016 12:27PM Rosevalley wrote: Mara- I am glad you have found strength through our posted trials. I remember when I first got ascites I really thought after looking at the stats that I was a gonner in 2-5 months. Everything I read painted a truly bleak picture and I felt so awful. Once I got the Pleurx drain and could get fluid off I was in heaven but there is very little written for patients about this journey. You can search and folks share little about malignant ascites and various treatments. Maybe they die too quickly, but if you live for a year as I have done, why not tell others what worked and what didn't. Maybe they can use the information to help themselves and their loved ones. I really wanted to post about malignant ascites and wide spread mets/ Lobular breast cancer. I truly have taken other peoples posts and asked my onc how about this? What about that? I get much of it from these postings -from others willing to share their journey. I also believe in painting a true clear picture. If I am miserable, say so. If it's doable, tell folks! The thing is we all metabolize drugs a little differently and one person might tolerate something easily. Like Ibrance, I wanted to take that drug so badly and it made me puke unrelentingly. I couldn't keep the capsules down. Most patients are fine with Ibrance. my Onc only has had one other patient respond the way I did, everyone else did great. So there is some caution in sharing. I want everyone to have everything work for years and years and be super responders! Blow the stats away live long!! Ruth there are perks to being very much loved old cats! Percy looks ancient. He also will pee on things left in the garage (dog bed and rug..) and we have had to throw out things. There is a liter box out there and 2 in the house, and a cat door... no excuse. He's just pissy or that's what he thinks of the dog!! Ha ha! Also if you go to a vacuum store you can buy a product that uses digestive enzymes to break down vomit, pee, diarrhea and food nasties in carpet and fabric called ALIVE. We have used in on carpet after the dog had diarrhea and used a carpet cleaner machine... no stain or smell. Amazing stuff. Gets out blood too- soak it in the washing machine or a bucket and water. Worth every penny. I thought I would pass that along to all old pet owners.. we need all the help we can get.

Lounging in the dirt amid the flowers, swatting at bee half heartedly. Sleeping so soundly you twitch... purring until your sides vibrate because someone you love gave you undivided attention. Being present. My cat Percy is so 100% present and lives in the moment.. Buddhist in heart. Our dishwasher has been making this awful smell when ever we run it.. like a burning electrical smell. It worries me. The machine is 15 years old, used almost once a day, now mostly every other day. Works well- but it's an alarming smell.. I guess dishwashers have a life expectancy of 8-12 years, so 15 is good. My DH wanted to have a plumber look at it but at that age why? Anyway we replaced it with the same Kitchenaide... sticker shock 600 on sale (150 off so they said) and a heafty sum to dispose and install. I was horrified at the cost of the machines. Most were 800 and up. Nothing lasts forever. Our dryer will be next as it is 16. Trusty old machine. I feel that way about my body. I know my markers are falling but I never feel good anymore. It was a lovely fall day, sunny 80 and I spent it inside. I was cold, my belly full and uncomfortable. It feels like a betrayal not to fight to the end, but I am tired. I wonder when I will just give up like the dishwasher... and start to smell bad. I am comforted by the sound of crickets out my window. They are the sound of summer and that reassuring sound of childhood. The hum of life in insects and the world. When I was a child at my Great grandmother's we would catch fireflies and let them go in the bedroom watching them... loving their flickering light. My brother and I enchanted by having "stars" in the bedroom. Funny the things we remember from childhood. Life is sweet and trying to stay here enduring chemo, ascites and aching joints is hard. Much harder then I expected it to be. Blessings to you all and thank you for letting me vent.

Little things sometimes mean big comfort changes. Today is supposed to be sunny and lovely. I intend to enjoy this day!

Posts.Content: Oct 13, 2016 04:21PM Rosevalley wrote: I have had the rug pulled out from under my feet too many times... I think Thanksgiving is doable and I hope to be able to plan a yummy vegan/ turkey feast. But I worry about after that. Still pulling gallons of fluid off. You know I have to ask you Kandy and others. The school for the deaf here grades the kids at the level they are at. SO for instance my 15 year old reads and writes at a 4th grade level and for her IEP (special education plan) they grade her on improvement at her level. Her level for math is 6th grade. She is technically in 9th grade. So she is justifiably proud that she has all A's and one C in health. I gently remind her that the level is for 4th grade and not 9th grade so there is HUGE room for improvement. She gets angry with me. "I have all A' s my teachers say so. I am in high school in 9th grade." She will get a modified diploma. It seems the school lies to the kids by painting a picture of success that simply does not exist except at the Deaf school. Any other kid in 9th grade would get straight F's for being years behind. What purpose is there lying to these kids and having them feel like they are honors material when they read and write like 4th graders on a good day? My kid thinks she will go to college. She has straight A's better then her sister. It's a horrible lie and paints an unrealistic picture of opportunities that don't exist and dreams and goals that are decades away... The kids will be humiliated and shocked once they hit the real world standards of community college. I also can't understand how the school gets away with it legally since you can't do this to a normal kid. My daughter is of normal intelligence and is only deaf. Over half the kids at the school can't read and write at a 3rd grade level. I see their texts and it's sad. The school excuses it's responsibility to teach the kids English by saying they are all English as Second Language learners since their first language is American Sign Language. They have to be culturally sensitive and provide all instruction in ASL. That's fine and one can be bilingual but you have to be able to read and write well enough in English to read an apartment contract, buy a car, pass a drivers license exam, read banking statements, recipes, instructions and directions or you are severely handicapped. The world will not provide you with an ASL interpreter for life - like it or not America thinks and works in English. I think it is horribly unfair the way the Deaf School doctors up these kid's expectations and sense of self when they eventually will have to produce a written piece of paper to communicate to a hearing clerk or Boss and humiliate themselves with poor grammar, wrong verb tenses and unintelligible sentences. That's my rant for the day.

Posts.Content: Nov 12, 2016 02:52PM Rosevalley wrote: I love the photos just beautiful. I feel like I get out and explore more of the world through the lens of your camera. I thank you for that!! Ruth there is nothing wrong with adoring a puppy. If they are loved and trained and enjoyed, they turn into great companion dogs for life. Sometimes getting other animals in the family to accept the newcomer is hard. Four years ago we had the family of our DD2's friend show up at our door 10 days before Christmas. The parents were getting a divorce and the Mom was making the 2 kids ages 16 and 10 give up their dog. Tearful pleading for us to take it. We did. She was a wild little terrier (15 pounds) and she got along with our 16 pound terrier older dog Flower who died at age 18 a year ago, but she never hit it off with our border collie. Our border collie actively bullied the little terrier and wouldn't let her out the doggy door, share toys, be near the gate to watch the neighborhood. This poor little dog lived in fear. We frequently heard yips of pain when the collie would nip her to get away. The final straw came last Feb when I went in the kitchen and our collie Tess had her mouth over Ruby's head and the little dog had her eyes shut shivering in terror. I smacked Tess and put her outside. That's when we decided to find little Ruby a new home. She was rusty red wiry haired doxy, russel mix... fiendishly cute. We took her to a no kill dog shelter near Portland, paid a 75$ donation, told them all her good points-housebroken, rides great in a car, plays like crazy, good with kids, cats and dogs, loves snow, walks and cuddles on the couch, washes easily in the sink dries fast, sweet and friendly, microchipped and spayed and current on all shots. Bad points- terrified of thunder and fire crackers drools and cries, shreds paper and dog toys. My kids protested. I said the dog needs a life and she is only 5 years old. It's not right to live with a bully dog. She was in the no kill shelter for less then 24 hours when a retired woman who lost her husband, adopted her for a companion dog. The last picture we saw was of little Ruby licking her new owners face in joy! So I am sure she was spoiled and loved and free from fear being the only animal in the house. A fine ending for a happy sweet natured little dog. The folks who adopt there pay 300 for the dogs and that money goes to help the other animals. It also ensures folks are serious about adopting. So happy ending!! Our grumpy 11 year old collie is happily enjoying her only dog status and doesn't have to share anything. :-)

Posts.Content: Nov 19, 2016 06:52AM Rosevalley wrote: Wow we live at the very edge of town, but in the city limits of a town of 150,000. There was a blue Jay killing a little garter snake in our backyard. Never saw that before... we've had possums, raccoons, Flickers, Towheys, woodpeckers, owls, hawks and herons all manner of critters... but never a snake. The blue jay is definitely winning this battle and will eat like a king. I was gardening once and grabbed a big old frog that jumped out of my garden glove and made me scream and fall over. My DH died laughing yep..watch out for those killer frogs. Smart allek! You just don't expect a big old soft 5 inch frog to come flying out of your handful of weeds. It's startling. We have a tiny pond and the fountain attracts lots of birds and animals. As far as my kids being there when I pass I think it's a bad idea. Two of these kids are adopted and have loss issues, abandonment issues. One kid is developmentally delayed. One kid has mental illness and is doing well with meds but it would be sending the wrong message to check out with meds as a way to leave the suffering of cancer( which I think it's legit ), because you could run with that and turn it into a way to leave problems and a mixed message that suicide is ok. I certainly don't want that as a legacy. I won't have them with me. It's not helpful. I will tell them I will die and we will have a chance to say our goodbyes.

Posts.Content: Apr 1, 2016 03:40PM - edited Apr 1, 2016 03:42PM by Rosevalley Holinone-Welcome to the club no one wants to be in. You have your new house and you just have to work harder at staying in it! May taxoterre kick cancer to the curb. Hey I've got cancer in my liver, lung, bones, ommentum, mesentery and malignant ascites.. drain every other day. I was in hospice in Feb. and because of Faslodex flunked out of hospice and from deaths door to life again. Holy crap what a miserable ride. But to get through hell.... keep going!! I think it was Churchill who said that. Well who ever said it; it's true. I made it through and feel better, not normal but better. Keep going. I made it to my DD3 15th birthday. We walked through the rose garden in Portland and the Crystal Springs Rhododendron Garden today to celebrate our 27th anniversary. We saw gorgeous colorful rhodies, lenten roses, poppies and little blue flowers. I do not have a camera on my old flip phone but the lakes, plants and flowers were wonderful. We saw a pair of bald eagles flying and hunting. There were flocks of Canada geese, goslings, a heron and a bunches of ducks. The weather was sunny 75 degrees. My poor DH has a cold but he managed a long rambling anniversary walk, bird watching and lunch. It was a wonderful day and we enjoyed it all. Living and enjoying something like this is the best revenge on cancer. Today we lived a life where cancer wasn't invited! Thank you for celebrating with me. It's not been perfect and in our imperfections and celebrating the tenacity of spirit and fortitude we raised 2 kids, one still to go and stayed married. We started out in Pennsylvania then to California and finally to Oregon. We have been through 4 dogs, 3 cats, 2 rabbits, mice and a guinea pig in 27 years. We lost 2 of the dogs to cancer, the guinea pig to cancer and 2 cats to renal failure. We have also suffered some chronic diseases in our kids. One DD is developmentally disabled but has done herself proud! (She works and can read and write and is doing well!) Our lives are the peaceable kingdom. We still have one dog, 3 cats and a canary! Everyone is old and spunky. Cancer has colored the journey for 9 years and we steal our lives back as we can. But you all know this because taking back our lives and living is why we are all here! (((hugs))) to all of us! Yay for all the folks on BCO who trudge the path and live and help others do the same. Thank you.

Posts.Content: May 25, 2016 07:30PM - edited May 26, 2016 12:53AM by Rosevalley Ebru- your post made me cry it was so beautiful. To understand the pull of life, the love of our families and the release into the universal unknown.. the great beyond life. I too feel its beauty and promise of release, no fear just love and joining the universe. We will meet you and I - souls bridged together. We will know each other through our common suffering and love. May your holiday by the sea replenish your soul. I am trying to let go of my need to wrap everything up into nice neat little packages. I want to fix things and leave things resolved and tidy for my kids and husband. Life isn't like that (neat and tidy) and while I know that; it is hard for me not to want to try. Letting go is so hard. Life is sweet and I want to stay. The Ibrance has not been bad; no more diarrhea and no reduction in the fluid I pull out of my belly. It reminds me of the cancer's presence as well as the aching in my bones. Otherwise I feel pretty good and try to carry on best I can. My counselor told me I look good today. I want to believe it and fool cancer. Leave me be to raise my children and live my life...cancer go away. Blessings to you all for your support. No one understands like you all do. I walk in the light of your caring. Thank you for the fiddle head photos feelin feline. That is one of my very favorite colors that tender green ofthe new furled ferns. I painted the entire inside of our cabin a light green to match the color of fiddle heads in spring. The color made me happy. Reminded me of rebirth and renewal. When I was a kid my favorite bedroom had pale celery green walls and a flower colored comforter in pinks and greens... like crab apples in spring time. Wow. Now that I live in Oregon where the rhodies and azaleas thrive I have even more spring time beauty. Our world is beautiful. Love to all.

Posts.Content: Jun 4, 2016 02:06PM Rosevalley wrote: Well at least Percy isn't the only one to pee on the bed when miffed. Oreo too eh? Bad old men they are... I tried so hard to have a good time at a restaurant for my DH's birthday. I felt ok but ate french fries and a grilled cheese thinking it was fairly lite. I didn't even eat half. I came home we talked and I took the Ibrance pill and threw up everything. So much for that dose tossed- 21 pills at 10,000 a month. Expensive mistake. So my poor DH came in hearing me puke.. ruining his birthday. So he's all sad and concerned. Sigh..We had a good time all the girls were here and it was fun. It still was fun even if it ended up so so. Eating is difficult. It seems all celebrations are around eating. My DD2 came home from college early to celebrate her Dad's birthday. I was draining fluid off to feel more comfortable. She walked in just as I started draining. She has a key. I was a upset she saw me doing it. A long catheter hanging out my belly connected to a vacuum bottle. It's a harsh reminded all is not well in cancerland. People don't drain containers of frothy ice tea off their bodies. She sat down said it "wasn't gross and no worries." Her eyes were wide though. What do you do with the container she asked... throw it out in the trash since they burn it. She was a little quiet and reflective after seeing that. I would have liked to spare her the image of her mother draining fluid off her gut but it's done. She watched it all. I am sad to leave her with such a memory and am upset I didn't drain sooner so she missed seeing it. I try hard to do my best at hiding the cancer's effects on me and living my life despite it all. This is not an easy task since my life revolves around pills, draining and treatments. On a lighter note a friends daughter's baby arrived safe and sound. She is lovely and blesses us all. Life goes on. Love to you all. rosevalley

Posts.Content: Jun 6, 2016 06:51AM Rosevalley wrote: Bestbird- lovely! It is a beautiful sunrise. We have very pretty sunsets here. The clouds and skies and mountains in Oregon are quite stunning. From a physical standpoint Oregon is a gorgeous state, so varied. I have lived in Indiana, Pennsylvania, New Jersey, Conn, Upstate New York, Oakland and Sacramento CA... and here for 16 years. Every state has it's beauty and loveliness if you take time to look and enjoy. I also spent many a vacation in Michigan and Florida visiting family. We are so blessed in America to have this entire country to explore and love. I am unabashed in my love for America. The people, land and animals are wonderful. We are the luckiest folks on earth. I have had many a fine vacation in Canada and enjoy going there. It is also gorgeous. Thank goodness for CBD oil from pot. It helps with nausea so much. It's a shame it isn't available everywhere. Feelinfeline- glad you joined the foxglove band wagon. I love the old varieties of plants - foxglove, Rose of Sharon, Lilacs, Hellbore... the ones not in favor. A fine English/Irish garden in full bloom is a heaven here on earth. Enjoy all those foxglove. Warning once you start they multiply like crazy and only bloom every other year. So don't pull them up if they don't flower. They will next year. My DH gives all our plants fish emulsion 2x a year and they grow like crazy.. epsom salts in water a few times a year does the plants good too. Be well sisters. Stay cool. Extra prayers to Patty because she is having an extra hard time with pain. (((Hugs))) to all rosevalley

Posts.Content: Oct 31, 2013 01:45PM - edited Oct 31, 2013 01:54PM by Rosevalley It's a good article as far as it goes. It has been my experience that if you "look good," you are good regardless of what you report, what scans say, labs etc. Which is weird, when you think at what length some oncologists will go to find new mets and get them before they even become an issue that the patient exhibits or feels. Some doctors won't bother looking until "it becomes and issue to you." Frankly I think that's too late, and you spend too much time back pedaling to repair and maintain function and health. I find Doctors believe scans, ultrasounds and reports more then they believe what they can see and feel and listen to, especially the patients' subjective reports of difficulty. This will take a whole generation of training to change, I think. Oncologists are specialists "fighting" cancer. Their focus isn't usually "Your idea of quality of life" especially when it comes to metastatic disease. They are doing their "job" when they keep you alive period. Palliation is a whole new field that needs to come to it's own. What needs to happen is a merging of palliative care and oncologic care when it comes to metastatic patients. We know this intuitively and the frustrations are plastered all over this stage 4 forum. Everywhere on these boards is evidence of "stop treating me like I am cancer/ body minus my emotional, psychological, sexual, working, spousal, mothering self." How things became so separated is a mystery to me. I think in a specialists mind, there is only so much they think they can focus on and be effective clinicians. When you can no longer function in a psych realm then it's off to a psychiatrist or counselor, sleep - sleep medicine, or dump on the PCP etc.. This leaves fractured care and unhappy frustrated metastatic patients.
Posts.Title: Is the Medical Community Finally "Getting It" for MBC women? AnacortesGirl AnacortesGirl

Posts.Content: Nov 1, 2013 12:21AM - edited Nov 1, 2013 11:31AM by Rosevalley I hear you! Just think how many commercials are aired during prime time for constipation! People are miserable when they are constipated, bloated and cramped. Life sucks. Pooping is wonderful, and worth spending big pharmas bucks for prime time spot. If you can't sleep for days on end, everything in life tanks. You can cope for a while, but then things unravel. Get sleep deprived long enough can make you nearly dysfunctional in all realms physical and mental. The sleep issue is critical and really gets swept under the rug. Poor sleep makes a person sicker then they already are! (They have linked insomnia with obesity which puts you at risk for osteoarthritis, heart disease, diabetes, depression and higher cancer rates...hmmm) We all know the pain issue can eat away at a person until they get depressed and despondent about life. (The neuropathy from Taxol nearly drove me over the edge and the joint pain from arimidex made me refuse to take it.) I find if I get enough sleep I can handle pain, irritation and everything else better. If no one listens to and intervenes with symptom management then you get non compliance, depression, frustration and anger. If you are already stage 4 and palliation is the focus then why aren't the symptoms managed better or even at all? It doesn't help me to read an article cataloguing all the common stage 4 miseries into neat percentages and spread sheets if you don't intervene! I really am curious and hopeful to see what palliative care doctors can do for metastatic patients; it sounds like a perfect marriage with oncology for stage 4 folks. I did read that their salaries are low; high 70s to 100k. Hard to pay off school on that. That may be why we don't see more of them. We should start a thread asking those with palliative care MDs what they think of their input. Has having one made a difference in their lives. I would like to know more. I have heard good things.

Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2013 11:01PM - edited Feb 11, 2013 11:03PM by Rosevalley Marywh- Everyone I have ever met who has had a family member commit suicide was devastated by it. There is such a cultural taboo against it. One can only wonder and wonder, what if.. It's so hard. I had to fight with my brothers to get them to agree with my Dad's wish for hospice. He was dying, in pain with multi system failure and lasted 17 days after hospice came in. It was time. My brothers were not ready. I wish more doctors took a proactive stance to intervene and "snow" folks who struggle and suffer with pain or breathlessness, especially if they ask for relief. The palliative coma sounds good for painful endstage disease. What I have seen is that intervention differs WILDLY between doctors, even oncologists. So I think the solution is to talk about what the doc is willing to do and what the patient wants. See if you see eye to eye. Pretty hard to request a very Catholic or religious medical doctor to break their faith for your needs. Might not happen. Then you switch or ask for hospice. It's interesting how we feel we "play God" euthanizing our pets. Another post above. I see it differently. We have a lovely brain and ability to use medical knowledge to assist in a process that is already in motion. I think we do a good job with our pets. I ran 900.00 worth of tests on my daughter's service dog (a 12 year old Golden) before I was satisfied that he had cancer, was in pain and was dying anyway. He was a 4 footed angel. Then we let him go, holding him and crying. I couldn't bear to put him down unless I was sure. I remember crying in the office with my 16 year old cat, who had end stage kidney failure."Do something!" I begged the vet. She said, "we don't do dialysis on 16 year old kitties." I asked "Is it because you can't or because no one ever asked you to?" The vet looked.. pained. We did subq fluids at home, until I looked into that cat's eyes and saw the misery. I had her put  down. The kid's and I wrapped her in her blanket and burried her under the rhodies in the front yard. Our medical care was keeping Daisy here longer then she should have lasted. Sometimes we need to accept death as natural.. it's hard.
Posts.Title: Sensitive question... Renae64 MartyMart

Posts.Content: May 6, 2015 08:54PM - edited May 6, 2015 09:02PM by Rosevalley You have every right to ask for another nurse. Getting IV's in is a skill learned over years, practice makes perfect, but there is a learning curve too! I am a very hard stick and ask for IV therapy RN's to put my IV's in. That is always an option too, unless it's a free standing clinic and they might not have them. Don't endure panic and misery by allowing someone who routinely misses you to keep at it - that's how folks end up with PTSD around various medical procedures. Also when you are fearful the veins vasoconstrict and it's harder to get the IV in too. Tell your NP or PA the name of the RN you would rather not have your IV started by and she'll pass it on so no one gets hurt feelings. You don't even have to do it! That goes for shots too. I don't know why this is in italics.. oops.

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2013 07:03AM Rosevalley wrote: I am happy with mine. It is far over just as your chest curves towards the arm pit. It takes a month or so to heal and get used to the "feel" of it. Ports are easy to use, great for chemo, labs and for use in an emergency. You can't beat them. The one the breast surgeon did had a longer thinner scar and laid flatter, and the port was flat. The one the radiologist did had a smaller scar more on my chest, more noticiable and the port is tilted slightly, makes accessing it a little tricky. Works fine though.I would recommend getting one. It's a quick surgery, you are in and out. Ports have very little issues compared to PICC lines and IVs. You will like it. The only thing you might think is odd is that when they flush the saline through it - you can taste it. Tic Tacs are good.

Posts.Content: Oct 2, 2015 11:15AM Rosevalley wrote: I just wanted to add that ascites really ruins ones quality of life and I have been suffering from it since May. The symptoms started in May and I got the first of 4 paracentesises which relieved the fluid in July. Of course with malignant ascites it just comes right back. I had a Pleurx catheter placed in my abdomen in August. This catheter has made my life SOOOO MUCH BETTER! They tap the fluid off every 3 to 4 days. I can breathe better, the nausea is better. I can eat instead of feeling full and miserable. They take off about 3 liters plus a week. I would recommend getting one. Your wife might be more comfortable. It won't of course "fix" the course of the disease but it will relieve the pressure and misery of the ascites. Then you can enjoy the time you have together. Ascites makes me very tired so I would imagine your wife might be tired too. After the taps I need to nap. Sometimes just being together in familiar surroundings is a great comfort and blessing, no need to fancy up or vacation unless it's a nice day trip. All folks react differently though and she will need to decide what is doable. I would tell the kids sooner rather than later and enjoy every moment with each other. Hugs to you and your family, this is a hard road.

Posts.Content: Apr 8, 2013 07:15PM Rosevalley wrote: I had mine done prior to getting stage 4.  You know had I known that I would be stage 4 - I would have kept them. You are never the same after BMX. I couldn't have done reconstruction because the skin is too tight on the left and the radiation melted it onto my muscles - seriously no way that skin would expand - it's crazy tight and I can't even lift my left arm as high as the right. It feels like you have a band (of scar tissue) across your chest 24/7. My scars are very attractive, thin as far as scars go - but no replacement for breasts. (From all perspectives, and I do miss the girls.) I hate the feeling of silicone prosthetics and flat refuse to wear them - flat chested and watching folks stare is rather amusing. It's been years and I have seen every expression! I don't care; I would rather be comfy. I would have been more comfy mentally and physically had I just kept them and gone for broke. So I would side with Chickadee and not get a BMX if you don't have one already and are stage 4.

The edema was rediculous. I have spoken with folks who think Neurontin is great for them. Biology keeps us hopping! Everyone is a little bit different. Talk to your doc before ditching the med and make sure they document the side effect.

Posts.Content: Rosevalley wrote: I have a family member who just finished breast cancer surgery, some reconstruction and has seen 2 different oncologists. One MO recommended chemo (CT)and then AIs,  and the other MO recommended the aromatase inhibitors. The cancer was grade 2, highly ER+, no lymph node involvement and clear margins. She had a double mastectomy. There are some other health issues but otherwise she is healthy and very active and totally loves life, kids & grandkids. She is in her late 60s. Both oncologists think there is only a 10% chance of a recurrence which means there is a 90% it won't metastasize. (sadly we all know stats aren't everything) I still suffer side effects from Taxol in my feet and recently had a bladder infection that I didn't even feel because of lost sensation from the Cytoxan I got in 2007! I don't think chemo is worth the risk in her case. I think she could take the aromatase inhibitors (femara, arimidex and aromasin) and biophosphates and if she got 5 years out of each heck she would be in her 80's! I would take the path that gives me the best quality of life and no risk of neuropathy or other SE. What do you women think? Double mastectomy 07/ chemo ACT, Radiation/ 07 Arimidex, 08 Aromasin, 2012 Faslodex, 2014 Afinitor / mets spine, bones 6/2015 mets to omentum, malignant ascites, lung, liver/ 2016 Herceptin, Doxil, Faslodex. Posts.Content: Feb 3, 2014 04:55PM Rosevalley wrote: It's funny back in 2007 I saw a number of oncologists. Everyone had a different reason, method or schedule they preferred. There really isn't a "set" criteria from their professional organizations, so you can't go check their recommendations against the "gold standard". One oncologist told me that (after I already had chemo) that he wouldn't have given me chemo because I had ER/PR percentages in the high 90s! He thought I would have done better on the hormonals. Wish I had heard that before I did the chemo! That ticked me off because of the SE from the ACT chemo back then were particularly miserable. Most of the oncologists I have seen are not interested in testing (labs, scans, tumor markers) at all, most of that I have gotten from other doctors. Can't really say about this new MO yet. I just think that sometimes patients react to what doctors have to say about their % of recurrence out of fear and don't really think about how great their risk is. (they focus on the 10% recurrence and not the 90% chance it won't come back) My relative has not had any PET scans for baseline. I think this chemo recommendation is based on her being in the grey zone, with a grade 2 tumor. I hope she picks a safe treatment. She's such a great person we would all hate to lose her. In particular I wish she could continue with the happy retirement she's enjoyed so far, and not have it tainted and diminished by side effects of chemo. She's very active and involved with lots of friends and activities. Thank you all for your input, I will pass it along. Good to get wide variety of perspectives lots to think about.

Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2013 09:33AM Rosevalley wrote: Interesting topic. We have always pushed for the minimum of a BA/BS degree as the bottom bar. My husband thinks that if a kid hears it from the get go then they rise to the expectations. There are some limits. Our one kid is DD and will need job skills and vocational rehab, that's the best she can do. We celebrate that. But the "experts" never thought she would learn to read and write - she does both really well, surprised all. That's what expectations will do. We thought she could and she does read and write. I knew a couple of college women who got accidentally pregnant and kept their babies. Neither did well, kid or Mom. The women didn't finish college, got stuck in low end jobs and their kids suffered through low income, multiple relationships until Mom found a stable one etc. It's sad. I have a friend whose daughter got pregnant and keeps trying to patch up the relationship with the child's Dad. The Dad is going no where, smokes pot, no job skills, no interest in getting job skills, has another kid he's paying child support on.. whew! Give it up and MOVE on! This guy only pulls her and the baby down. A moment of passion and lifetime of misery? I think birth control should be given out to women in highschool - pills or implants free of charge, until emotional maturity catches up with them. The stakes are too high for life time failure. But what's done is done. Celebrate the co-workers Grand baby cause it's not their fault. Maybe Mom will go back to finish what she started. As others have pointed out over 50 years ago it was common to have accidents. I was one too! I asked my Mom about how if I was 3 weeks early and she got married on... she quipped "the invitations were out!" I laughed!! My Grandparents wanted college for her and she never went, had  3 kids instead. Wedding plans were fast, she was just 18. Such is life.

Posts.Content: Nov 17, 2013 01:33PM Rosevalley wrote: I can not offer any assistance except an ear to vent! A shoulder across the pond to lean on. I hope there are laws to assure that you can stay in the place you live with support from your husband. I hope you are getting support from the father of the other two children. See if there are any support groups available or assistance. As far as your 3 year old goes, see if there are any early intervention autism services or groups in your area. I also have an autistic child that was very hard to deal with when she was 3 years old - an escape artist, behavior issues and language delays etc. So I know what you are going through. (My child is also mildly retarded and deaf even more challenges.) If your child also has global delays using early intervention services to maintain language, modify behavior and keep on track for school can be a life saver! Early intervention WORKS with autistic kids, but it works slowly. My child can read and write and care for her basic needs because of early intervention. We also used respite here when my autistic child was young. Then you can get out for a little bit. Having an autistic child is stressful all by itself! If you don't take care of yourself, you can not take care of the kids. If the whole picture looks overwhelming then bite off bitty pieces and deal with things hour at a time like was suggested above. Keep everything simple and basic. I am sorry things are so hard right now. Life is frequently unfair. May things get better soon.

Posts.Content: Dec 20, 2013 08:40PM - edited Dec 20, 2013 08:43PM by Rosevalley Lots of good advice here. Think of depression as a medical diagnosis... diabetic = insulin or oral, appendix burst = surgery, infection = antibiotics. So there is no stigma attached to trying medication to intervene on mood and misery. You don't have to stay on it if you don't like the side effects. They do take 4-6 weeks to kick in. If one doesn't work there are others and it might take a while to find the right "fit." Chemistry differs in folks, be kind to yourself give it time to work.  what the hell try it. You can stop if it is not your thing. At this stage of our lives why do you care if it's long term? What ever makes life easier and "lighter" seems sane and reasonable to me. Ativan does nothing for me. It works wonders for others. I have never tried Xanax. I do definitely have a screaming case of S.A.D. and use a Phillips Blue Light (bought at best buy) and you sit by it for 1/2 hour. It helps. I live in Oregon and the wet dreary cold grey days get me down. Even when it's grey they recommend getting out in to direct light to reset the brain. Good luck with your journey.. MBC is a mental struggle for everyone.

Posts.Content: Aug 29, 2014 12:40AM Rosevalley wrote: Ask for diuretics and do the manual lymph drainage. Physical therapists can teach you how.  I have seen machines with sleeves that mimic manual lymph drainage but they have all been for arms. Maybe they have one for legs, I don't know. I just saw an ad in a magazine. You know they have wedge pillows made of foam to place under your head to raise it, folks with hiatal hernias and reflux need that, but no reason you couldn't use the wedge under your leg while sleeping or reclining. Most medical supply stores carry them and you can get them on line. Sue (post above) is right about the compression strength needing to be decided by someone who knows. Also make sure the garment doesn't roll and act like a tourniquet or you will create more problems then you solve! Good luck. Can you get your shoes on?

Posts.Content: Rosevalley wrote: I hope my experience is out of the normal. I was diagnosed in 2007 with a 4x5cm mass on the left breast, 8 month after a "clear" mammogram. My core biopsy said it was ductal cancer, later it was determined it was lobular (in 07 and again in 2012). I asked my oncologist at the time for films to solve the huge descrepency between film size 1.5cm and palpable mass size 4x5cm. She refused. No film for the other breast either. That's the difference between an almond and a plum! So I waltzed off to surgery where it ended up being 5.2cm unclear margines and a metastatic lymp node 1.5cm.. oh and ILC not ductal. More surgery. This oncologist changed the measured size in her notes, shaving off a cm in all directions. I found that out later. She blamed the surgeon and the surgeon blamed her.  I fired her. I fired him too. Then the 2nd oncologist I had  started out ok and then later seemed very wishy washy. I would ask him very specific questions and get no answer. I asked for my chart notes and there were things in there I didn't know. I asked "where did you get this information?" He refused to answer me. Once we sat silently for minutes in the office and would not answer me and he said I didn't need radiation, after his treatment plan specifically called for it. He arranged for me to meet the radiologist. He refused to say why he changed his mind. I got the radiation, had quite a lot of difficulty with it.I lost all confidence in him and left again. So that leaves me with oncologist 3 (male) 2008 I saw him for 8 months. In that time he didn't do any testing and no labwork of any kind. I was a stage 3A breast cancer patient. I asked him why and he said  next time. I left. Oncologist 4 (woman)2010, again said that there are no standards for follow up care, everything is left to the doctor. She did no testing or labwork. She gave me reglan for the GI issues I was having. I never went back. Fast forward to Feb 2012, oncologist (male) number 5, also did an exam said I was fine and he would see me in a month. No labwork no tests. I left. I figured the game playing was just too much. Everyone demanded I take AI's and I refused. I had a horrid time on arimidex and aromasin. I was only offered Ai's and nothing else. It was like being held hostage, take the Ai's or you get nothing. Not even information on whether the cancer is back or not. By this time April 2012, I was having lots of GI issues and went in for a 2nd colonoscopy. I have a redundant colon and they couldn't get through. So I had a virtual CT colonoscopy and they picked up lytic areas all through my spine. My GI doctor ordered a PET scan and it showed wide spread boney metatases through out my skeleton, spine, (one small compression fracture), multiple fractured ribs, my pelvis,sternum, femurs and humerus all lit up. My alk Phos. was up, calcium was also up - had anyone bothered to look. I had back pain and some rib pain but got around pretty well. Also for the second time in 6 years they checked my tumor markers; they were 768. The only other time anyone checked them was the breast surgeon back in 2007 and they were 25. I got referred to an oncologist the GI doctor recommended and so far He seems decent. I asked him why no one offered me faslodex before now. He said you need to be stage 4. How do you get to be stage 4 if no one checks labs or does scans? He said to focus on doing things now. Faslodex works really well and I tolerate this fine. I still don't trust oncologists. So my question to you folks. Would you have stayed with the oncologists who refused any labwork or testing?  If so why? Have any of you been told that you had to take a class of drugs you had difficulty with before they would offer any other treatments? Double mastectomy 07/ chemo ACT, Radiation/ 07 Arimidex, 08 Aromasin, 2012 Faslodex, 2014 Afinitor / mets spine, bones 6/2015 mets to omentum, malignant ascites, lung, liver/ 2016 Herceptin, Doxil, Faslodex. Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2013 01:59AM Rosevalley wrote: Bon- I think  the middle docs 3,4,5 were because they found out I put in a complaint to the State Medical Board about the sheer volume of mistakes when I was first diagnosed. ( the circus around oncologist 1) I didn't go into all the detail but it would make your eyeballs pop. I got a letter back from the board saying "medicine was not an exact science" and the just was "buyer beware." Thanks for nothing I thought. Who polices these folks?  But to be  a late stage BC patient and have an oncologist do no labs or anything in 8 months is insane, but I guess legal. I did take arimidex and aromasin for 8 months. Tamoxifin was out, TIA and a bood clot in the right leg without taking it so too big a risk. Once my chart hit the next doctor I was doomed, repeat performance. I finally gave up. You can't make doctors do something if they don't want to. I even tried going to 2 oncologists out of my state and it made no difference at all. They stick together and all did nothing. I wondered if this current oncologist would follow the others, but I guess the GI doctor's referral and the PET scan results meant he had to offer me something... other then AI's. I thought all doctors took an oath to "do no harm?"

Posts.Content: Aug 23, 2013 03:12PM Rosevalley wrote: Most folks do not have the "luxury" if I am so insane to call it that, of thinking about their own death. Death sneaks up from behind and bam no decision. I think the particularly hard part of Metastatic disease is that you know death is waiting, watching, ever present - working it's way through your being physically and mentally. If the drugs and SE don't get you the "mental" aspects will do as much damage. Most of what is discussed and shared here is how this f... disease "eats away" at a person from all sorts of angles. We make some sense of it all by sharing the path we have been forced to travel. My Mom is slowly being eaten away by dementia at age 74. she smokes like a stove and that doesn't help. She is some what aware of her mind slipping and will be at times nasty and uncharacteristically mean. She wasn't this way before. Since she is with it enough her sister and I can not intervene. So we watch from the side lines as she spends in to her nest egg, buys way over her budget, refuses meds, drives when no sane person would EVER let her...and we can do nothing. We have tried. She's on a destructive path as miserable as cancer with half a brain working. She's gotten type 2 diabetes and won't take her meds. Driven to the other side of Florida, run out of gas, cops intervene, get her on the road again.. she never thought that driving 12 hours in the wrong direction was odd. She will take a swing at you if you try and force her to do something. Frankly, I think as some one posted earlier... ending up like that staring blankly in a nursing facility...hmmm maybe dying earlier is better. I agree with that. Life is hard. I am sick of all the cancer crap, dispite having lots of things I do enjoy. On a day to day level, I just wish my youngest kid would pull it together instead of making everyones' life miserable. Cancer doesn't stop the the other hard aspects of child raising, economics, work, marriages and everything else from being any less taxing. Cancer just makes it that much harder and a person more tired. I would never do chemo again, ever. Dying doesn't scare me at all. There is a lot of freedom when you stop grasping at wanting more  life.

Posts.Content: May 4, 2016 02:00PM - edited May 5, 2016 01:54AM by Rosevalley This last Christmas I spent the second time as close to death as ever. I still have moments of wondering why am I here and how is it I didn't die? The first time was 2014 when my bone marrow got eaten and my hemoglobin was 5. I had no energy and a very high heart rate. Hard to do anything when you have no hemoglobin to attach oxygen to! It would have been a peaceful death though very tired and sleepy. I had a fair amount of bone pain and that was relieved by meds. Then the turn around with afinitor and 20 transfusions. Back to life. This last Christmas herceptin and doxil failed and the cancer caused a bowel obstruction that backed up all my fluids and caused abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting. The N/V was relentless and MISERABLE. Honestly it's a horrible way to die. I ended up in the ER twice with intractable nausea and dehydration just heaving. I cried. I was besides myself with misery my kidneys had started to shut down. Zofran and pain patches barely worked, constipation and explosive vomiting scared me. They finally allowed me to give myself fluids at home, then added faslodex and I started to turn around. It took weeks to turn the corner.. weeks of muscle weakness, shaky unable to eat much, feeling full and barely able to write a sentence my hands would shake. The faslodex is working and now I can eat more, drink, walk, write legibly and feel more alive then dying. I used to be a nurse so I have seen people die. I am not scared of death. The dying process can be scary. Dying of liver failure and kidney failure is mostly peaceful. You get more and more toxic from organ failure and your labs get wonky and you fall asleep. There is pain associated with some systems/ organ shut downs and that can be controlled with fentyl patches and other meds. Stopping eating and drinking is also an option. Dying of a bowel obstruction is miserable because everything backs up and vomiting bile and secretions daily sucks. Brain mets is no picnic either. I have seen a few brain mets patients with no pain. I opted for death with dignity meds and paid 3, 068.00 for the script. My Catholic health insurance wouldn't cover it. I can not revisit another 2 months of puking and 24/7 nausea. My PCP has graciously offered to come to the house when it is time to take the med and be there to help me and my DH. I won't have the kids there. When faslodex and Ibrance fail I will take the DWD meds and die a peaceful death. My DH is fine with me taking the meds and he know the cancer will return and the puking and nausea. He doesn't want me to go through that again. Our will is done and papers are in order. Now we wait for the last of the options to fail. Trying to live in the mean time is the hardest part. Thank you for bringing up this topic. My family won't talk about it. We live with a dinosaur in the room! Here with others facing the same we can explore and hash out what living with cancer and preparing for death is really like.

Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2014 10:34PM Rosevalley wrote: You know I totally feel those of you that work and need the income should apply for the benefits that you paid into. You won''t see social security probably..(I don't know your age) but that's what the program is there for! I also think folks are clueless about what cancer does to a person, the fatigue, pain, loss of sleep, weird aches and side effects. That woman was an insensitive clod who said "they can print more money." How rude.   I mean 4 weeks ago I walked into a new oncologists office with a hemoglobin of 5.5. I was tired, short of breath and wiped out but I walked in from the car to the office. That's critical, 5.5. If it gets much lower you can just keel over and check out. But I look better then I am. Isn't that true of many of us? We wear our cancer on the inside where you can't see it. We are quiet about it and to the outside world we look good enough. I won't apply for SSI/ disability retirement, despite paying into it for decades. Why, because I have a disabled kid who will need a transplant eventually and I want the system to have as much money as they can. I want my daughter to have my portion and we are lucky to able to live on my husband's income. I have already been told that I should watch her and not place her because she's my responsibility and not the states. Even though she's 20 and the state has to care for her, legally. She lives with us and we love her. So I guess I will never get a break, except respite. I have even had family members say things like "why should the state watch her and pay all those thousands out of our tax money, she's your responsibility and you don't work." My husband and I didn't go out alone or for an over night stay somewhere for 14 years.. no one would watch her. It's like being under house arrest. People make you feel guilty for asking for what is rightfully yours or for asking for what you need even. I'm off topic sorry. Fitztwins is right. It is jealousy and cluelessness. Like being off work to undergo treatment is a picnic. A year with cancer would shut those folks right up but quick!

Posts.Content: Jun 30, 2015 02:16PM - edited Jun 30, 2015 02:17PM by Rosevalley Having gone through bilateral mastectomy and a nasty cellulitis around one of the drains and lymphadema in my left arm... ya know - It's no walk in the park all that surgery. If I knew what I know today, I wouldn't have done what I did because it's made the last 8 years a trial. If your tumor is small and you can be treated with antihormones (tamoxifen, aromasin, arimidex, fermara), shoot I would so go that route. You will always be stage 4 so relax and focus making your QOL the very best it can be. I started out lllA and did all this crap to keep from being stage 4 and none of it helped. There was a teacher at my daughter's school who also had lllA BC. She was given chemo first, shrunk the tumor. They did mamosite radiation to just that area. She kept her breasts and has taken AI/ hormonals for 8 years. She is a happy camper. Her body is whole and she has normal sensation, no lymphadema, no scars, tightness, pain zip. Her QOL is outstanding. Wish that I had had her team instead of mine. Best to you whatever decision you make.

Posts.Content: Apr 16, 2014 01:06AM - edited Apr 16, 2014 01:14AM by Rosevalley Boy this is all food for thought. I can not help but think that thousands of years of genetic tweaking have made our particular genetic make-up agreeable to milk, wheat, meat or soy... name your "problem." So it stands to reason that Eskimos who wouldn't be able to get wheat or sugar in the snowy North would be "devastated" by it's effects. Same goes for any isolated tribe of folks. Tibet populations can survive on lentils, onions, meat and yak milk butter etc. and we would be wildly sick by such a diet. But these peoples have learned to survive on what they can grow in the area where they live. I wonder when you mix genetic traits like most Americans (mutt mixes from all over) if you do not invite vunerability to diet, stress and poisons out there in our environment. Scientists have a fair amount of evidence that histamine reactions like you get with allergies and a body with too much cortisol gets sick. That's why aspirin seems to work in lessening inflammation in colon cancer and heart disease. They need to know more about the effects of inflammation. I agree it seems too complex for a simple - "scratch dairy and you are cured." Just out of curiosity I will share a personal story. We have 2 adopted kids. One is from South Vietnam. She can not digest cow milk and it gave her skin rashes, diarrhea and no weight gain. We had to switch her milk based formula to soy before the kid could gain weight. To this day she prefers soy milk. Yogurt and small amounts of cheese seem ok. My Chinese daughter can drink milk, eat cheese, yogurt and pretty much anything with no ill effects. She hates corn and tomatoes and refuses to eat them. Here are 2 Asian kids who can tolerate different foods. So our philosophy is give the kid what they prefer to eat since they know how it makes them feel. (With in reason.. no diet of popcorn and chocolate..) Our biological daughter (Swedish, Irish, Scottish, German Mutt) loves dairy, vegetables, fruit  and soy. She's a vegetarian. There is lots more than just diet to explain BC.

Posts.Content: Oct 25, 2014 12:48PM Rosevalley wrote: Yep you have some mental baggage and therapy will help.  My recipe for "no fear" - stay in the present moment. Repeat -"future never comes, past is finished and  life exists only in the present moment." When you repeat it over and over, train yourself to stay present. Do not dwell on fears - accept them, do not push them away.  Just an acknowledgement "oh fear there you are, have a seat. I see you and feel your pain." Don't try to make it go away just acknowledge and let it go. Amazing what just noticing and not judging will do. You do not have to "do anything." Just notice "fear is here." Let it be. You can take the wind right out of the sails of fear and panic and calm down. This takes practice and more practice. You need to be willing to sit with something that makes you very edgy and uncomfortable, but the rewards are profound. I wish you luck. Find a therapist who has some knowledge of mindfulness training. Sounds like you have some background in this already. Find your way again; you are just lost in the woods. Find the trail markers and continue on!! I wish you peace on a path you have no choice to travel! Yep we all got re-routed on this cancerland path. Therefore we must teach ourselves how to cope.  Vent! Be gentle with yourself! Be well.
